His dream is to have his own house.  He faces the challenges that life presents.  In his free time he plays sports, especially soccer.

loans.use: to buy agricultural supplies.

loans.name: Maria Emilia

texts.es:
María, se decidió por un nuevo crédito, debido a la motivación de los buenos resultados que ha tenido antes, le será de ayuda para comprar pollo, carnes, verduras, aceite, pan, galletas, jugos, gaseosas,  huevos, condimentos, sal, dulces, boquitas, etc., de esta manera surtirá la tienda y seguirá funcionando la venta de comida
EL financiamiento anterior le permitió surtir la tienda con productos y tener la materia prima para elaborar la comida que tiene a la venta, sus ingresos han tenido una leve mejoría y los utiliza en el pago de las cuotas y mejorar el estilo de vida familiar.
texts.en:
María has decided to take out another loan because of the good results she achieved with the previous loan. This will help her to buy chicken, meat, vegetables, oil, bread, cookies, juices, sodas, eggs, condiments, salt, sweets, snacks, etc. By this she will stock up her business and will continue to be able to sell food.

Her earlier loan enabled her to stock up her store with products and to have he ingredients to prepare the food she sells. Her income has risen a bit and she uses it to pay her dues and to improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to buy chicken, meat, vegetables, oil, bread, biscuits, juices, sodas, eggs, condiments, salt, sweets, snacks, etc.

loans.name: Shamim

texts.en:
Shamim has successfully built her business manufacturing rugs and shawls with the support of Kashf Foundation and Kiva. By this time, she has attained a good number of customers and makes a good amount of income to contribute to the family income. 

Previously, with the help of a Kiva loan, she was able to expand her business. Now she is in her seventh loan cycle and has applied for a loan of 40,000 PKR to purchase good-quality wool, nylon, polyester, and polypropylene fibers. This will enable her to increase her sales to more cities and to gain more profits.

loans.use: to purchase good-quality wool, nylon, polyester, and polypropylene fibers.

loans.name: Kousar

texts.en: Kousar is a 35-year-old married woman who has been running a business of animal sales for many years. She buys animals (baby goats & calves) at low prices, raises them and then sells them at the market at higher prices. The business is doing well enough to provide her with a decent life. She has four children of which two daughters are of school-going age. She is very motivated to provide them with a beautiful life. She has improved her business to meet day-to-day expenses of her household. It’s her sixth year with Kashf Foundation. Now, she has requested a loan of 40,000 PKR to purchase more goats and feed for the cattle. She dreams of providing good quality education for her children.

loans.use: to purchase more goats and feed for the cattle.

loans.name: Zuhra

texts.en: Zuhra is a 36-year-old married woman and a mother of five children. The income generated by her husband is insufficient to cover all household expenses, so she initiated her business of milk sales. She has been doing it for many years and has become famous for providing good quality milk in her locality. With the support of Kashf Foundation, she has gradually improved her business. Currently, she requested a loan of 40,000 PKR to purchase another buffalo. This will help her to increase her sales which will ultimately help in generating more income for her.

loans.use: to purchase another buffalo.

loans.name: Antonio De Jesus

texts.es:
Antonio es un Joven emprendedor con todas las pilas puestas para enfrentar el mundo y tener una vida plena gracias a sus esfuerzos.

Se dedica a la compra y venta de equipos celulares y accesorios tecnológicos que en un principio inicio vendiéndolos a sus familiares y amigos, pero le ha ido muy bien en el negocio y comenzó a venderlo a todo el público en general y a pesar de su poco tiempo en funcionamiento ha tenido buena acogida en el sector.

El desea ampliar su oferta de productos y mejorar aun más sus ventas, es por esta razón que solicita un crédito para la compra de una vitrina que utilizara para exhibir sus productos de una mejor manera y así aumentar sus ventas. 

Tiene grandes esperanzas en el negocio y piensa que su futuro puede mejorar considerablemente gracias al apoyo de estas entidades que hacen lo posible para que las personas puedan soñar con una vida mejor y más estable.
texts.en:
Antonio is an enterprising young person who is all set to take on the world and have a full life thanks to his efforts.

He buys and sells cellular equipment and tech accessories. He started selling them to his family and friends, but the business has gone very well for him and he started to sell to the general public. In spite of the short amount of time he has been in operation, he has been well-received in the market.

He wants to increase his product offering and improve his sales even more. This is the reason why he is asking for a loan to buy a display case that he will use to exhibit his products in a better way and thus increase his sales.

He has great hopes for the business and he thinks that his future could improve considerably thanks to the help of these organizations that do as much as possible so that people can dream of a better, more stable life.

loans.use: to buy a display case

loans.name: Suria

texts.en: Suria is a 34-year-old married woman. She has been running a business of milk selling with her husband for many years. She has two buffaloes to milk and sells their milk to many of her neighbors along with butter and cheese that she makes from the milk. She looks after the buffaloes and performs the task of collecting milk from them while her husband sells it to different places on a daily basis. She has 5 children. She needs to earn much more to meet their everyday expenditures including food, clothing and education. In order to make huge profits, Suria has requested a loan of 40,000 PKR to buy one more buffalo to cater to more customers. She expects a boost in her earnings through her larger sales.

loans.use: to buy one more buffalo.

loans.name: Rukhsana

texts.en: Rukhsana, age 43, is a married woman and the mother of 8 children. She is striving hard to meet their daily expenditures. Her husband’s income is not sufficient to meet the daily expenditures of the family. Four years ago, she started her business of selling clothes to contribute to the family income. Now, she has become famous for selling good clothes in her town. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns enough to lead a decent life. In order to inflate her sales, she requested a loan of 45,000 PKR to buy a new collection of clothes in different colors and designs to meet up with the increasing demand. In addition to repaying the loan, she will use part of the revenues to deal with personal expenses. She is in her 6th loan cycle with good credit history.

loans.use: to buy a new collection of clothes in different colors and designs.

loans.name: Dauda

texts.en: Dauda is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Dauda joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Danladi,Musa, and Bulus. Dauda is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Dauda will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Dauda can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to provide more food and clothing for my family.” Dauda is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Safia

texts.en: Safia is a 46-year-old married woman who has been running a business of milk selling with her son for the last 6 years. They have two buffaloes to milk and sell their milk to many of their neighbors. She looks after the buffaloes and performs the task of collecting milk from them. She sells the milk at different places on a daily basis. In this way, they are able to obtain good profits. She needs to earn much more to meet the household expenditures including food, clothing and health. In order to make more profit, she has requested a loan of 45,000 PKR to buy one more buffalo and feed for the cattle that she already has. She hopes to increase her production capacity of milk which will ultimately help in generating more cash.

loans.use: to buy one more buffalo and feed for the cattle.

loans.name: Modesta De Jesus

texts.es:
La señora Modesta de Jesús de 70  años de edad es soltera, no tiene hijos que dependen de ella, se dedica desde hace 11 años al negocio de compra venta de ropa nueva y calzado, su negocio es en su local propio ubicado en el mercado de San Lorenzo.
Doña Modesta  sus clientes son los amigos y conocidos que llegan a diario a visitarle, es una mujer trabajadora que desea seguir luchando para apoyar a sus hijos y nietos. También cría ganado en una propiedad que tiene fuera de la cuidad.
Doña Modesta  está solicitando el préstamo para la  compra de blusas, vestidos, faldas, pantalones, camisas, calzonetas, etc. ya que viene la feria del lugar y tiene varios pedidos y quiere  aprovechar para obtener más utilidades, está muy contenta de seguir trabajando con Prisma, es su cuarto crédito que solicita.
 Su sueño es mejorar su negocio.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - Julio del 2014.
texts.en:
Señora Modesta de Jesús, age 70, is single and has no dependent children.  She has been selling new clothing and shoes for 11 years. She has her own stall in the market in San Lorenzo, and her customers are friends and acquaintances who visit her daily.  She is a hardworking woman who wants to continue fighting to support her children and grandchildren. She also raises livestock on a piece of property that she has outside the city.
 
Doña Modesta is requesting the loan for the purchase of blouses, dresses, skirts, pants, shirts, shorts, etc., as the local fair is drawing near and she has a number of orders, and she wants to avail herself of this opportunity to earn greater profits. She is very happy to continue working with Prisma, and she is requesting her fourth loan.

 Doña Modesta’s dream is to improve her business.

San Lorenzo, Honduras—July, 2014

loans.use: to purchase blouses, dresses, skirts, pants, shirts, shorts, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Limousine Group

texts.en:
Mele, who is in her early 30s, is married, with two school-aged children. 

She runs a charcoal store where she purchases sacks and resells in small bundles, a business she has been with for five years now. Mele works from 8am to 6pm daily and is able to make a small profit each month. She tried to look for loan support, so as to replenish her store with more charcoal. Her desire is to open another successful business (food shop). 

This will be Mele's seventh credit request via Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous credits, paid back successfully, to buy stocks for her store. Mele received an extra income, which she used to buy a house cupboard, a mattress, and a bed. She is so happy with Kiva's loan support, she managed to purchase extra sacks of charcoal to sell more. She is now requesting another credit to replenish her charcoal store. 

Mele will share this credit with her group, Limousine Group, which totals five members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to replenish her charcoal store.

loans.name: Maria Cecilia

texts.es:
María, requiere de más capital para invertirlo en la comprar elotes, yuca, tomates, repollo, bolsas, plátanos, sal, harina, etc., con los que continuara elaborando la venta de antojitos y teniendo ingresos con los que se mantendrá cancelando puntualmente sus cuotas y cubriendo los gastos familiares.
El préstamo anterior le ha sido útil para mantener el negocio surtido con la materia prima para los antojitos, sus ingresos se han mantenido estables y ha logrado mantener su buen record crediticio.
texts.en: María needs more capital in order to buy corn, yucca, tomatoes, cabbage, bags, bananas, salt, flour, etc., with which she will continue making and selling snacks and earning income, with which she can continue to punctually make her repayments and cover the household expenses. The previous loan has been useful to her in keeping the business supplied with raw materials for the snacks. Her income has remained stable and she has succeeded in maintaining her good credit history.

loans.use: to buy corn, yucca, tomatoes, cabbage, bags, bananas, salt, flour, etc.

loans.name: Maria Auxiliadora

texts.es: La señora María Auxiliadora, es una mujer emprendedora de 54 años de edad, viuda, quien se dedica a la comercialización de huevos en su domicilio y por encargo en su comunidad, el crédito lo solicita para la compra de cajillas de huevos, con el objetivo de mejorar sus ingresos.
texts.en:
María Auxiliadora is an enterprising woman of 54 years. She is a widow and she works selling eggs in her home and also on order in her neighborhood.

She asks for a loan to buy boxes of eggs in order to improve her income.

loans.use: to buy boxes of eggs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for tuition for a 2-month call center training program that can get him a job paying about $270 monthly

loans.name: Raymart

texts.en: Raymart is a 22-year old Vocational School undergraduate who lives in Bago City. He lives with his aunt, a widow and a Barangay (Town) Treasurer who earns PHP 3,000.00 per month (USD 68). His parents are separated and they have their own family in Manila. Raymart and his younger brother would do menial jobs such as construction work and planting sugarcane tops just to have money and buy their food. But Raymart knows that his chance to have a decent and a high paying job would come. And when he heard about Bagosphere’s training program he took the risk in undergoing the selection process, and he eventually passed. Raymart aims to finish his training so he can send his brother to school and provide for their basic needs. Your help in funding his loan would greatly motivate Raymart to achieve his goal of a better life.

loans.use: to pay for tuition for a 2-month call center training program that can get him a job paying about $270 monthly

loans.name: Sakina

texts.en: Sakina is a 37-year-old married woman and the mother of six. She has been running a business trading cloth for many years. She purchases a variety of cloth from the main city and then sells it to the people of her vicinity. She has become famous for selling good quality cloth in her community. She has requested a loan of 40,000 PKR from Kashf Foundation to buy stock of different varieties of cloth for the next season, taking into account the choices and tastes of her customers. In this way, she will be able to earn more income through greater sales. She hopes to have a good experience with this loan.

loans.use: to buy stock of different varieties of cloth for the next season

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is a 36 –year old single mother of two and lives in a rural village in Bago City. She belongs to a family of nine. Her father is not working in the farm anymore because of old age, and her mother died a few years ago. Jane has 6 siblings and the older brother works as part time motorcycle driver while the youngest brother is working in a sugarcane plantation as hired helper.
Jane is a sales agent for a health drink company and she’s earning PHP 4,000.00 (USD 91) per month. She gets PHP 5,000.00 (USD 113) monthly financial support from the father of her children, but this is not even enough for her children’s needs. Jane would like to earn more for herself and for her family. Now that she has passed BagoSphere’s selection process, she needs your help to finance her tuition. So she can help her father, provide basic needs for her family, and send her children to school.

loans.use: to pay for tuition for a 2-month call center training program that can get her a job paying about $270 monthly

loans.name: Aletha

texts.en: Aletha is a 37-year old college graduate and lives in a rural village in Pulupandan. Her father works as a tricycle driver and farmer, and her mother tends the needs of her children and a part time cook in a local eatery. Aletha’s husband Stephen helps in his family’s mini-convenience store and they have been living with his family since then. Their total monthly family income is only PHP 6,000.00 (USD 136).  Aletha has long seen the need to help her husband but did not have the means until she learned about the 2-month training program of BagoSphere that could lead to a call center job. Now that she has passed BagoSphere’s selection process, she needs your help to finance her tuition. Once Aletha starts earning, she can help her siblings provide her family’s basic needs and then save money for her future children.

loans.use: to pay for tuition for a 2-month call center training program that can get her a job paying about $270 monthly

loans.name: Susana Eugenia

texts.es:
Susana es una mujer de 45 años de edad soltera, madre de dos hijos y se dedica a la venta de comida y administración de un taxi.
Ella es una mujer independiente, fuerte y muy luchadora, su carácter emprendedor y sus necesidades económicas la han llevado a tener varios negocios para poder pagar los gastos de su familia, ella cocina y prepara comida todos los días para el almuerzo y para la cena en un pequeño puesto de comida donde acuden sus clientes y se llevan la comida a diario.
Susana es de tez morena, cabello negro largo y estatura mediana, su habilidad en los negocios la ha llevado a comprar un auto para administrarlo como taxi y con eso ayudar a pagar los gastos escolares de sus dos hijos. Sus negocios tienen necesidades como; la compra de comestibles por mayor para abaratar costos, y la reparación y mantenimiento de su automóvil para recibir la renta diaria. Susana sueña tener su casa propia y mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia.
Es por esos motivos que Susana solicita un préstamo para la compra de comestibles por mayor y la reparación de su taxi y con los beneficios ayudar a pagar los gastos escolares de sus hijos.
texts.en:
Susana is a 45-year-old single mother of two children. She sells food and runs a taxi.

She is a woman who is independent, strong, and a fighter. Her enterprising character and her economic needs have led her to have several businesses in order to be able to pay her family's expenses. She cooks and makes food every day for breakfast and for dinner at a small food stand where her customers come and take away the food every day.

Susana has brown skin and long black hair and is of medium height. Her skill with the businesses has led her to buy an automobile in order to run it as a taxi, and to use this to help pay the school fees of her two children. Her businesses have needs, such as buying wholesale groceries in order to lower costs, and repairing and maintaining her automobile in order to receive daily income. Susana dreams of having her own house and improving her family's quality of life.

It is for those reasons that Susana is asking for a loan to buy wholesale groceries and to repair her taxi, and to help pay her children's school fees with the profits.

loans.use: to buy wholesale groceries and to repair her taxi, and to help pay her children's school fees with the profits

loans.name: Roger Antonio

texts.es:
El señor Roger Antonio de 42 años de  edad, vive en su casa propia junto a  sus hijos, se dedica desde hace 5  años al negocio de venta de hamacas, lasos, gamarras, etc.  Sus clientes son todos sus vecinos y también personas que viajan por la carretera que conduce al sur de Honduras.
Don Roger Antonio sus clientes son personas que transitan hacia Tegucigalpa o Choluteca,  el ofrece buena atención y buenos productos.
Don Roger es un hombre emprendedor  con deseos de salir adelante y lucha día con día para mejorar su calidad de vida, está solicitando el préstamo para surtir su negocio de materia prima como seda, palos, hilo, telas, etc. su producto es de muy buena calidad y es por eso que tiene varios clientes que le encargan este producto, espera que con las inversión que realice a su negocio le genere los ingresos necesarios para mejorar su calidad de vida y la de su familia.
Su sueño es  crecer con su negocio para mejorar su calidad de vida. 

San Lorenzo, Honduras - Julio de 2014
texts.en:
Roger Antonio, age 42, lives in his own house with his children.  For five years he has been in the business of selling hammocks, ropes, and halters, etc.  

His customers are all of his neighbors and also people who travel on the road and are driving to southern Honduras.  Roger Antonio’s customers are people who are traveling to Tegucigalpa or Choluteca.  He offers good service and good products.

Roger is an enterprising man with the desire to get ahead.  He struggles day to day in order to improve his quality of life.

He is requesting the loan to stock his business with raw material like silk, poles, thread, and fabric, etc.  His product is very good quality, and that is why he has several customers who order this product from him.

He hopes that this investment that he is is making in his business will generate for him the income needed to improve his quality of life and that of his family.    His dream is to grow with his business in order to improve his quality of life.

San Lorenzo, Honduras – July, 2014

loans.use: to stock his business with raw material like silk, poles, thread, and fabric, etc.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en: Susan has been operating her farm for more than four years and she earns well from this. Having a passion for meeting the family's needs, Susan especially lends more effort to providing for the needs of her children. She had to work hard with determination to have a better income to provide their children with a better education than they had. To improve the farm productivity, she took a new loan from GDMPC microcredit to buy organic fertilizer. In the future, Susan hopes to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to buy organic fertilizer

loans.name: Libertina

texts.en:
Libertina has successfully paid back a Rp 10.000.000 loan in just four weeks! She achieved this through sales of a micro-solar lighting system that can connect up to four light bulbs and has two USB ports for charging phones and running a radio.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting Rp 20.000.000 loan. She will use the loan to buy more stock of green technology products and provide solutions to her customers’ problems: difficult access to clean water and frequent power cuts on the island of Sabu, off the coast of West Timor.

"Since I moved to Kupang decades ago, I rent a semi-permanent building that is used for kiosk, bedroom, and kitchen. I dream to have my own house where my kids can have bigger space to do their activities such as studying and playing. Few years ago, I borrowed money from the cooperative to buy a land. The last installment from this loan was paid using the money I got from Tech Kiosk business. Now on that land, my husband and I start to build a simple house that is nearly done. All profit I got from this business is allocated to buy materials for the building."  

Libertina is grateful for the support to increase earnings to complete her new home.

loans.use: to help introduce simple, clean energy products to her community

loans.name: Rahila

texts.en: Rahila is a Babban Gona farmer from Dau. Rahila expressed that she is driven by one goal; to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Rahila to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, she finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Rahila can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Rahila, is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season. By doing so, Rahila will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what she plans to do with her income from this season, she said: “I plan to use the money I make to provide more food and clothing for my family”. With this loan, Rahila will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Musa

texts.en: Musa is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Musa joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Sunisi,Habiba, and Hassan. Musa is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Musa will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Musa can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to provide more food and clothing for my family.” Musa is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for tuition for a 2-month call center training program that can get her a job paying about $270 monthly

loans.name: Yuliana

texts.en:
This loan will help Yuliana introduce simple, life-saving technologies such as solar lamps, water filters and clean cookstoves to her community.

Yuliana runs a mobile phone shop. She is interested in early childhood development and is now studying at a local university while working as substitute teacher at an early childhood development school. She supplements her salary selling health products from a multi-level marketing company.

To support her family, Yuliana has joined Kopernik’s Tech Kiosk network to sell simple life-changing technologies. She will use the loan to buy stock and grow her income.  She sees the technologies as very practical and useful, and great technologies to sell alongside the health products she promotes.

loans.use: to pay for green technologies to sell to customers

loans.name: Yonotan

texts.en:
This loan will help Yonatan introduce simple, life-saving technologies such as solar lamps, water filters and clean cookstoves to his community.

Yonatan parents are farmers. He wanted to continue in school but his elder brother did not finish so he was taken out also. He became a hawker selling in the market when he was 13 years old. He is married with five children.

When he heard about Kopernik’s Tech Kiosk program, he immediately jumped on board; not only for its obvious business opportunities but also for the benefits he could bring to his community.  He sees the technologies as very practical and useful to his and other families. Clean water, safe methods of cooking, and affordable solar lighting are excellent solutions to a lot of the social and economic issues in his community.

loans.use: to pay for green technologies to sell to customers

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is a married woman. She has 3 children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Asha has operated a charcoal selling business by selling from her home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces stiff competition from other operators in her business.
 
With the 40,000 KES she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business

loans.use: to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale

loans.name: Nireda

texts.en: Nireda operates a general store to make a living. In addition to this, she also sells barbecue to earn extra income. For many years in running the business, she earned well to support the needs of her family and was able to sustain it. She borrowed a loan from GDMPC to purchase additional grocery goods and home products to sell. She hopes to improve the business to ensure a better source of income for the family in the future.

loans.use: to purchase additional grocery goods and home products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase sewing supplies.

loans.name: Alexander

texts.en:
This loan will help Alexander introduce simple, life-saving technologies such as solar lamps, water filters and clean cookstoves to his community.

Alexander’s parents are farmers. He wanted to be a teacher but his parents could not afford to pay school fees. He completed primary school and became a construction worker at age 13, but stopped when he suffered fron a disease and became an amputee. He is now a farmer, and activist at an NGO for people with the same disease. 

To support his wife and child, Alexander has joined Kopernik’s Tech Kiosk network to sell simple life-changing technologies. He will use the loan to buy stock and increase his income. He sees the technologies are simple, much needed and affordable. He hopes to sell many solar lights as the surrounding villages do not have electricity. Clean water, safe methods of cooking, and affordable solar lighting are the exact solutions to a lot of the social and economic issues in his community.

loans.use: to pay for green technologies to sell to customers

loans.name: Dayyabu

texts.en: Dayyabu is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Dayyabu joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children. Dayyabu is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Dayyabu will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Dayyabu can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Dayyabu is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Sakina

texts.en:
Sakina is a 52-year-old, married woman. She has three children. Sakina’s son (also shown in the photo) has been running a ‘Dahi Bhallay’ stall from many years, near their house, with Sakina’s assistance. ‘Dahi Bhallay’ is a special food of the subcontinent, prepared by soaking deep-fried balls, made from ground lentils, in thick yogurt. 

Sakina is a very hard-working woman. Her husband also helps by taking orders from customers and handling delivery of food to respective places. 

In order to meet the daily expenses of the business, Sakina has requested a loan of PKR 40,000 to buy from the market at lower rates, stocks of yogurt and ‘bhallay' (deep-fried balls), along with spices, vegetables, and packs of oil. In this way, Sakina would be able to increase her sales. Sakina wishes to utilize her earned profit on her family’s well-being.

loans.use: to buy stocks of yogurt and ‘bhallay’ (deep-fried balls), along with spices, vegetables, and packs of oil.

loans.name: Iffat

texts.en: Iffat has a passion to serve the community through quality education. She has been running a private school with her husband (also shown in the photo). It is a building on a large plot of land built for the purpose, with a great scope for expansion. She has a dream of expanding the school and getting more children enrolled. There are over 200 students (more than half are girls) currently enrolled in the school, including their own son. She encourages extracurricular activities at the school, and has a large ground where she organizes sports and other student events. Now she has applied for a loan of 100,000 PKR through Kashf Foundation. She wants to spend the loan to complete the construction of a new classroom for her expanding student enrollment, as well as to repair and renovate the school.

loans.use: to complete the construction of a new classroom and to repair and renovate the school.

loans.name: Haseena

texts.en: Haseena is a 38-year-old married woman. Her husband is a laborer. It was very tough for Haseena to manage her household needs with the small income of her husband. Therefore she decided to help her husband in earning. For this purpose she started her business of cloth trade. She buys cloth of different fabrics in various colors and designs from the market at wholesale rates and then sells them to the people of her community. She has a varied customer base and is able to earn enough through her business. Haseena is requesting a 45,000 PKR loan from the Kashf Foundation to buy a wide variety of cloth in different colors and designs to attract more customers and expand her inventory. She expects a boost in her earnings with her loan and she plans to spend the part of her profits on the betterment of her family members.

loans.use: to buy a wide variety of cloth in different colors and designs.

loans.name: Betseba

texts.en:
This loan will help Betseba introduce simple, life-saving technologies such as solar lamps, water filters and clean cookstoves to her community.

Betseba’s parents are farmers. She wanted to become a tailor but only completed elementary school as her parents did not have enough money to finish her education.  Betesba complete a sewing course and started sewing at age 15. She runs a small shop and takes sewing orders.  She is married with five children.

When she heard about Kopernik’s Tech Kiosk program, she immediately jumped on board; not only for its obvious business opportunities but also for the benefits she could bring to her community.  She sees the technologies as very efficient and simple. Clean water, safe methods of cooking, and affordable solar lighting are perfect solutions to a lot of the social and economic issues in her community.  

This loan will bring in additional income to support her large family.

loans.use: to pay for green technologies to sell to customers

loans.name: Jhon Gideon

texts.en:
This loan will help Jhon introduce simple, life-saving technologies such as solar lamps, water filters and clean cookstoves to his community.

John’s parents are farmers. He wanted to be a lawyer and studied human rights and advocacy, however did not complete his studies as he wanted to work first. He got a job in a food processing factory. Currently he works as a social worker at a health centre. He is married with one child.

To support his family, Jhon has joined Kopernik’s Tech Kiosk network to sell simple life-changing technologies. He will use the loan to buy stock and grow his income.  He sees the technologies as very practical and useful. 

When he heard about Kopernik’s Tech Kiosk program, he immediately jumped on board; not only for its obvious business opportunities but he sees the technologies are simple, much needed and affordable. Clean water, safe methods of cooking, and affordable solar lighting are the exact solutions to a lot of the social and economic issues in his community.

loans.use: to pay for green technologies to sell to customers

loans.name: Agustina

texts.en:
This loan will help Agustina introduce simple, life-saving technologies such as solar lamps, water filters and clean cookstoves to her community.

Agustina’s parents are farmers. As a child she dreamed to be a successful business woman but due to financial difficulties only completed high school.  She took a cooking course but at age 21 had a job with a clothing manufacturer. 

To support her husband and two children, Agustina joined Kopernik’s Tech Kiosk network to sell simple life-changing technologies. She will use the loan to buy stock and grow her income.  She sees the technologies will help the community be more energy efficient and save money.  

This loan will bring in additional income to support her family.

loans.use: to pay for green technologies to sell to her customers

loans.name: Rachel

texts.en: Rachel is 27 years old. She is married with two children aged one and two. They not yet going to school. She has been selling beer like Primus, Mutzing and Skol, and Fanta for the past four years. Her husband works as a barber in a salon. With the loan, she would like to buy more beer to sell. The profits from the business will be used to renovate her house. And she wishes to expand her business and in the future, she would like to own a big bar with extra bartenders.

loans.use: to buy more beer such as Primus, Mutzig and Skol to sell.

loans.name: Theresia

texts.en:
This loan will help Theresia introduce simple, life-saving technologies such as solar lamps, water filters and clean cookstoves to his community.

Theresia’s parents are farmers. She wanted to be a teacher and completed a bachelors degree. She works full time managing church administration and as a mentor on a childhood development program. Her sister Marta (right) runs a small shop and Theresia (left) will display the technologies there and sell to her sister's customers. 

To support her husband and two children, Theresia joined Kopernik’s Tech Kiosk network to sell simple life-changing technologies. She will use the loan to buy stock and pay off a mortgage on a piece of land they have purchased. She sees the technologies have great benefits and will mean customers spend less money on kerosene.

loans.use: To pay for green technologies to sell to her customers

loans.name: Kasimu

texts.en: Kasimu is a 46-year-old farmer from Dankwaire.  As a Babban Gona member, Kasimu is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Kasimu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare,  double the national average of 14. However, Kasimu is ambitious and is aiming to reap 40 bags per hectare this season.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to educate my children; Hassan, Isiyaku, and  Nija. My overall goal is to make more money for myself and my family.” With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving these goals.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Herodias

texts.en:
This loan will help Herodias introduce simple, life-saving technologies such as solar lamps, water filters and clean cookstoves to her community.

Herodias’ parents are farmers. Herodias wanted to be a teacher but only completed junior high school due to financial difficulties in her family. She completed a cooking and sewing course through a women’s group but became a shop-keeper. She makes additional income tutoring at a kindergarten. Herodias is a widow, aged 66.

When she heard about Kopernik’s Tech Kiosk program, she immediately jumped on board; not only for its obvious business opportunities but she sees the benefits and cost savings one can achieve by using the technology.

loans.use: To pay for green technologies to sell to her customers

loans.name: Maximiliano Guillermo

texts.es:
Maximiliano, invirtió de buena manera el crédito anterior en la compra los materiales básicos para cultivar maíz, su productividad fue mayor, pudo vender más, mejoro sus ingreso y da a su familia mejor alimentación, vestuario  y salud.
Para mantener constante su progreso se decidió por un nuevo préstamo para comprar abono, insecticidas, semilla, herbicidas y plaguicidas, para preparar todo lo necesario para su próxima siembra, espera tener buenos resultados.
texts.en:
Maximiliano invested his previous loan well, purchasing the basic materials for cultivating corn.  His productivity was greater, he was able to sell more, he improved his income, and he gave his family better food, clothing, and healthcare. 

To maintain his progress, he decided upon a new loan. It is for the purchase of fertilizer, insecticide, seed, herbicide, and pesticide, in order to make all the necessary preparations for his next planting. He hopes to have good results.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer, insecticide, seed, herbicide, and pesticide.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to obtain a water pump for irrigation

loans.name: Delicate

texts.en:
Delicate, 44, is a business owner and farmer from Chibombo District, Zambia. He is asking for a loan for a water pump that will help him irrigate and expand his vegetable crops.

Delicate has been growing tomatoes, cabbage, and green peppers on his farm to supply large markets in Zambia’s capital city, Lusaka. Using buckets, he has been drawing water from a nearby well to irrigate his crops. This is an extremely labour intensive task, especially now that it is the dry season.

Rent to Own worked with Delicate to create a business plan for this gardening season and will deliver the water pump directly to his farm. Rent to Own also provides training on how to use and properly maintain the pump, and will check in to provide support until he has paid off his loan.

With a water pump, Delicate will be able to ensure his garden is properly irrigated during the dry season, and will even be able to expand his production.

loans.use: to obtain a water pump for irrigation

loans.name: Zahida

texts.en:
Zahida is a 45-year-old married woman and mother of four children. She had a difficult time a few years ago due to her husband's business’ failure. Therefore, she decided to assist her husband in initiating a new business nine years ago. Today, they own a well-established business of furniture selling. They have a large number of satisfied customers. 

Zahida is currently in her ninth loan cycle and has requested a loan amount of 55,000 PKR from Kashf Foundation. Zahida intends to use this loan amount to buy material such as wood, screws, furniture polish, etc. to create a means of increasing revenues. 

Her dream is to improve the living standards of her family.

loans.use: to buy material such as wood, screws, furniture polish, etc.

loans.name: Agripa

texts.en:
Agripa is 40 years old and is a farmer in Chibombo District, Zambia where he lives with his wife and three children. He is requesting a loan so that he may obtain a water pump from Rent to Own.

During the dry season in Zambia, Agripa grows and sells vegetables to support his family. Dry season vegetable production is big business for many small farmers in Chibombo District.  Agripa even has an agreement to supply vegetables to a local processor. He plans to use this water pump to expand his production and increase his income.

Rent to Own has completed a business plan with Agripa, and will deliver the water pump directly to his farm. Rent to Own will also provide training on how to properly use and maintain the water pump, and provide on-going support until his loan is complete.

This year Agripa will grow several different high-value vegetables, including green peppers, green beans and butternut squash.

loans.use: to obtain a water pump for irrigation

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to obtain a water pump for irrigation

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to obtain a water pump for irrigation

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more energy saving cookstoves to sell to her community.

loans.name: Maria Juana

texts.es:
Maria tiene 47 años de edad vive en el cantón San Miguel Provincia de Bolivar su estado civil es casada vive con su esposo y sus seis hijos.
Es integrante de la ventanilla rural Ambrocio laso que se dedican a las labores agricolas.
 
Maria se dedica a la agricultura y siembra de papas y habas, también a la crianza de pollo de canchón utilizara el dinero del crédito para ciclo corto con el apoyo del crédito incrementar su negocio, ella realiza las compras  de insumos en Chimbo.
Su sueño es tener un carro para llevar a vender lo que cosecha ella enfrenta los desafíos que se le presenten en la vida en su tiempo libre le gusta acudir a la fundacion de la comunidad.
texts.en:
Maria is 47 years old and lives in the San Miguel canton in Bolivar Province. She is married and lives with her husband and six children. She is a member of the rural shop Ambrosio that is engaged in agricultural work. 
 
Maria works farming potatoes and beans and raising chickens. She will use the money from the loan to increase her business and purchase supplies in Chimborazo. 

She is facing the challenges in her life that come her way. Her dream is to have a car to help sell what she harvests. In her spare time she likes to go to the Community Foundation.

loans.use: to buy agricultural supplies.

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en:
Jacqueline, 35 years old, is married with five children aged from 5 and 15. They all go to school. Her husband is a farmer. 

Jacqueline has been selling beans, sorghum and maize for the past six years. With this loan, she would like to expand her business to a high level of being a supplier of agricultural products. The profit from the business will be used to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To buy more beans, sorghum and maize to sell

loans.name: Husan

texts.en:
Husan is from a rural area. He was born in 1981. He is married and has three children. His children are adults. 

Husan has been busy growing crops for more than ten years. He earns additional income from animal husbandry. Husan feeds mainly cows. His father and brother help him with managing the business. Husan is the main feed keeper of his large family. He is going to increase working capital and maximize profit. He is asking for a loan of 7,500 Somoni to buy cattle. He awaits your mercy.

loans.use: To buy cattle to increase his working capital

loans.name: Ma. Cristina

texts.en:
At 37 years of age, Ma. Cristina with her husband, works hard to earn a living for their 5 children. All their children are currently going to school, of which one is attending a special education school due to hearing disability. 

7 years ago, Ma. Cristina worked as a salesperson for a shop selling computers and laptops. However, with the birth of her child with hearing disability, Ma. Cristina was obliged to stay at home and personally take care of her child. To augment the income of the family, Ma. Cristina opened a small store in their home.

In March 2014, Ma. Cristina availed a loan of PhP 5,000 from SEED which she used to add up canned goods and other food items in her store. On her second loan now, Cristina availed a loan of PhP 7,000 which she plans to buy bottled purified water, soda drinks, and electronic load which are highly demanded by customers of her store. 

On the long term, Ma. Cristina is aiming to continuously increase her stocks and be able to complete her general store. She hopes that with these she will be able to support her family's needs, and specially contribute to the  education needs of her son with hearing disability.

loans.use: To buy bottled purified water, soda drinks and electronic loads which are demanded by customers in her store.

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida, single at 47 years old, takes care of five of her nieces and nephews. Without any children, Aida took it upon herself to help her siblings by adopting their children and sending them to school. 

To earn, Aida owns and manages a store which has grown in terms of stock size and income over the years. She joined SEED in 2010 and at that time availed a loan to help her buy rice, canned goods and other food items to increase her stocks. Earnings from this business, and availing reloans from SEED, Aida was able to have her store repaired to increase the space and for stocks security. Also, Aida was able to buy a Videoke Machine which she rents out in the community during occasions.

On her 10th loan cycle now with SEED, Aida plans to buy cooking pots, food display trays and ingredients specially meat for an eatery business. Aida has seen the opportunity of increased income with the lack of eatery or stalls selling cooked food in her area. With her expertise also in cooking, and a stable main business of a general store, Aida is confident she will be able to make this business work and be profitable as with her previous business undertakings.

With the increased income, Aida hopes to continuously support her nieces and nephews in their school needs.

loans.use: To buy cooking pots, food display trays and ingredients for her new eatery business.

loans.name: Wilmer Antonio

texts.en: Wilmer lives in a community in the Department of Colón Honduras. He is a farmer (corn and beans), age 30 years who lives with his wife and one child. It is clear that Wilmer works hard to maintain his family and at night, after a hard day of work, the conditions in the house are not very good due to the lack of electricity. They currently illuminate their home with kerosene lamps because the electrical utility grid does not reach this rural area. The family wishes to spend more time together, extending the light hours to spend quality time. Wilmer is requesting a loan to purchase a complete solar electric system from Soluz Honduras.

loans.use: to purchase a solar home system to substitute the use of kerosene lamps and firewood, reducing expenses and improving the health of his family

loans.name: Victorina

texts.en:
Victorina, at 59, still needs to work hard to sustain the medication of her sick husband. While their children are all working, the support coming from Victorina's children is hardly sufficient in as much as her children have their own families to support now. 

When Victorina's husband became sick four years ago, she and her husband decided to set up a small store in their house. Selling usual food items consisting of canned goods, toiletries, laundry needs and snack items, Victorina was able to earn enough for their day-to-day expenses and shoulder some medicines for her husband. In 2011, Victorina went to SEED's office which was just near their residence, to inquire for the loan. She went through the process and was consequently provided with a first loan. With the first loan from SEED, Victorina was able to increase her stocks and earn more. 

From her earnings, Victorina decided to invest in rooms for rent. She had the extra space from her house repaired and converted into two rooms for single bed-space occupancy or for renting out to a small family. The earnings from these rooms for rent ensured Victorina's steady monthly income which sustains her husband's medical checks-up and medication.

On her 8th loan now, Victorina is continuously innovating with her business. She plans to buy rice, sugar and condiments in bulk and have those repacked prior to reselling to her store. Victorina realized that repacking food items enables her to earn more compared to selling those in usual packs in kilos. For condiments such as pepper and salt, Victorina says that her income triples and at the same time she is able to respond to her customer's buying capacity in retail.

With this business realization and plan, Victorina hopes to earn and save more for her to be able to set up another room for rent and therefore add up to another stable source of income for her family.

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar and condiments which she will repack and sell in her store.

loans.name: Sokna's Group

texts.en: Sokna’s group live in a rural village in Kompong Thom province in Cambodia. Sokna makes a living cultivating rice and trading groceries, fruit and fish to support her family. In their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. Having a water filter at home will help each of these women to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: To buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for their family.

loans.name: Vantha's Group

texts.en: Vantha’s group live in a rural village in Kompong Thom province in Cambodia. Vantha makes a living cultivating rice and fishing to support her family. In their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. Having a water filter at home will help each of these women to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: To buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for their family.

loans.name: Sarom's Group

texts.en: Sarom’s group live in a rural village in Kompong Thom province in Cambodia. Sarom makes a living cultivating rice, fishing and working as a farm laborer to support his family. In their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water.  Having a water filter at home will help each member of the group to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: To buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for their family.

loans.name: Thary's Group

texts.en: Thary’s group live in a rural village in Kompong Thom province in Cambodia. Thary makes a living cultivating rice and trading in fish, rice and porridge to support her family. In their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water.  Having a water filter at home will help each of these women to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: To buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for their family.

loans.name: Aurora

texts.en:
Aurora, 52 and widowed, supports her three children through her bakery business. 

Having grown up in a family whose main source of income generation is baking, Aurora has sufficient knowledge and experience in managing a bakery. This has been their family's bread and butter, especially when Aurora's husband died and left her to take care of the family's needs and their children's education all by herself.

In 2012, Aurora became a partner of SEED through her sister who invited her to join an Orientation Seminar. At that time, Aurora was in need of additional capital to buy flour for the increased demand on her baked products. She was granted a first loan in SEED and was a good paying partner all through out. With her good repayment record, Aurora was able to get further loans which has helped her increase also her produce of various bread and baked products. To date, Aurora has hired three helpers from her neighborhood for her business. 

Today, Aurora is taking up another loan to buy materials and pay the labor expense for the repairs of her bakery space. Aurora wants to expand her bakery space and make it more presentable for her customers to have a better look on her products. With this, Aurora hopes to increase her income more and be able to continuously support her children's needs.

loans.use: To buy materials and pay the labor for the repairs and expansion of her bakery space.

loans.name: Shyam Maya

texts.en:
Shyam Maya is 35 years old. She is married and has two children. Many years ago, she established her vegetable farming business. Working seven days a week and four hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid three loans from Patan BPW, and she used her most recent loan to buy seeds and fertilizers. In the future, Shyam Maya plans to lift up the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support.

Over 70% of Nepal's economy is agricultural. Typically, Nepali households grow crops on small plots of terraced land. Rice (bhat), lentils (daal), and vegetables (thakari) are the staples of the Nepali diet. With a Kiva loan, BPW's borrowers are able to purchase greater amounts of seed and fertilizer. With more seeds and fertilizer, a borrower is able to grow cash crops to be sold in the local market. Such crops allow households to move beyond subsistence and provide much-needed cash income throughout the year.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Gulo

texts.en:
Gulo is a 44-year-old married woman from Sagarejo district. She lives with her husband and son, who works in the mandatory army. The only person who generates income for the family's welfare is Gulo. She works as a private worker at many kinds of activities. She generates insignificant income that isn't enough to cover even everyday expenses. So the family lives in poverty and needs help to achieve normal living conditions. 

This hard-working woman requested a loan to start her own stable business. But her request was rejected several times, due to her unstable financial condition. At last Gulo's request was approved thorugh the joint initiative between Kiva and Credo that gives people who are at a loss a chance to start their own businesses. So Gulo was approved for a loan of 3,000 GEL and plans to purchase stock of fruits and vegetables and start trading in her district. 

Gulo and her family rely on the goodwill of lenders and highly appreciate Kiva lenders' help.

loans.use: To start a business selling fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Nino

texts.en:
Nino is 30 years old, a young divorced woman. She lives with her two young children in Kutaisi, West Georgia. The only source of income for her is money transfers from her mother. Nino married at an early age and wasn’t able to get an education and so she has no university degree, which is one of the main reasons for her unemployment. She looks after her children and stays home, but she has a great desire to be involved in a trading business. 

Nino couldn’t request a loan from financial institutions, until the Start Up program began, which is a joint program of Kiva and Credo. She requested a loan of 300 USD to begin selling clothing. She plans to go to Turkey and purchase the products at wholesale prices and then resell them among her friends and villagers. This will give her a chance to earn income and not have to depend on her mother. Nino will provide a better future for her children.

loans.use: to begin selling clothes

loans.name: Khayrullo

texts.en:
Khayrullo is from a rural area. He is a careful father of a child. 

He has been busy with animal husbandry since he lives in a rural area and has a good opportunity to develop this kind of business. Khayrullo buys cows, feeds them for some months, and sells them in a local market. He has worked in this way for more than five years. Khayrullo is the only breadwinner in his family since his wife is a housewife. 

He is asking for a loan of TJS 3,000 (somoni) to buy cows because he is going to increase his working capital. He awaits your mercy.

loans.use: to buy cows.

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Meet Simon. Simon is 31 years old and lives with his young family in Chibombo, Zambia. He is asking for a loan so that he can obtain a water pump to help irrigate his vegetable garden.

Last year, Simon used buckets to draw water from a nearby well and irrigate his crops of fresh greens and tomatoes. He used the profits from this to buy oxen, goats and cattle. This year he is hoping to expand his garden, and increase his profits, while reducing the labour required to provide irrigation.

Rent to Own has worked with Simon on a business plan for this gardening season and will deliver a water pump directly to his farm. Rent to Own also provides Simon with training on how to properly use and maintain the water pump, and will check in to provide support until he has paid off the loan.

With a water pump Simon will be able to reduce the time he spends watering his crops, and will no longer have to draw water by hand. He is already planning on growing a larger portion of corn and tomatoes that he can sell at a local roadside market in Chibombo.

loans.use: to obtain a water pump for irrigation

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles, 55, is a farmer in Chibombo, Zambia where he lives with his wife and 6 children. He is asking for a loan so that he can obtain a water pump that will help him irrigate and expand his garden.

Vegetable gardening is big business for many rural farmers in Chibombo district. Charles grows vegetables on his small farm to sell at one of the roadside markets. Last season he grew tomatoes, watermelons and fresh maize. With the profits he was able to pay the school fees for his children and invest in livestock. 

Because it is the dry season in Zambia, water needs to be applied to the crops regularly, often brought to the garden by buckets from a nearby well or stream. A water pump would significantly reduce Charles need for labor and allow him to further expand his gardens.

Rent to Own has worked with Charles on a business plan for this gardening season and will deliver a water pump directly to his farm. Rent to Own also provides Charles with training on how to properly use and maintain the water pump, and will check in to provide support until he has paid off the loan.

loans.use: to obtain a water pump for irrigation

loans.name: Shaitu

texts.en: Shaitu is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Shaitu joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Salisu, Ksmilu, and  Nafiu. Shaitu is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Shaitu will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Shaitu can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Shaitu is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Zeinab

texts.en:
Zeinab is a 37-year-old married mother of two, who started her own tailoring business in 2006, with a long period of experience. She enjoys her business. 
Zeinab is a hardworking woman, who helps her husband earn their livelihoods. In addition to tailoring, Zeinab also has a small area in her shop where she sells home products. Her tailoring work attracts attention to the home products (and vice versa).
 
Zeinab is skilled at what she does and works hard to improve her business as much as possible. For this reason she is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua, Kiva's partner, in order to increase her business merchandise with newly released textiles.  In addition she needs new business tools to prepare for the end of the holy month of Ramadan celebration requests.

Zeinab's business increases during the holy Eid Al Fitr celebrations, a three day Muslim holiday that marks the end of Ramadan, since most people mend old clothes or request new tailored dresses and many other items. A new textile collection and necessary tools would help a lot during this season and the coming days. 

Zeinab hopes to expand her business by opening a special clothes factory in the future.

loans.use: To increase her business merchandise with new released textiles, in addition  to obtain new business tools to be ready for the end of Holy month of Ramadan celebrations requests

loans.name: Anju

texts.en:
Anju is 31 years old. She is married and has two children. Many years ago, she established her tailoring business. Working seven days a week and eight hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid four loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent loan to buy raw materials for her business. In the future, Anju plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support. 

In the Kathmandu Valley, clothing is made to order. Tailor stalls line the streets where store owners sell material and work their sewing machines. These skilled tailors make school uniforms for children as well as the the traditional women's kurta surwal and men's daura surwal. With a Kiva loan, BPW borrowers are able to purchase additional cloth material or sewing machines that will increase production and profitability.

loans.use: to buy raw materials for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Jose Martin

texts.es:
José, requiere de un nuevo préstamo por que necesita comprar abono, herbicidas, plaguicidas y semilla, para continuar cultivando granos básicos, otra parte será de utilidad para surtir la tienda con los productos que cubren las necesidades de sus clientes comprara aceite, arroz, jabón, detergentes, bebidas, golosinas, sal, azúcar, pan, etc.
José comenta que el crédito anterior la ha brindado muchas oportunidades de crecer económicamente, ya que su negocio es más rentable, su familia es la principal beneficiada.
texts.en:
José is in need of a new loan because he needs to buy fertilizer, herbicides, pesticides, and seeds in order to continue farming staple grains. The rest of the loan will be used for stocking his shop with products that meet the needs of his customers; he will buy oil, rice, soap, detergents, drinks, snacks, salt, sugar, bread, etc.

José mentions that the previous loan has provided him many opportunities for economic growth, as his business is more profitable; his family is the main beneficiary.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, herbicides, pesticides, seeds, oil, rice, soap, detergents, drinks, snacks, salt, sugar, bread, etc.

loans.name: Godebelthe

texts.en: Godebelthe is 56 years old. She is married with seven children, and her husband works as a businessman. Godebelthe has spent seven years selling foodstuffs, such as beans, sorghum, and carrots. With the loan, she expects to buy more beans and carrots for sale. The profit from her business will be used to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: to buy more beans, sorghum and carrots for sale.

loans.name: Martha Lorena

texts.es:
Cada mañana, tras haber tomado su tacita de café caliente, con mucha energía Martha inicia sus actividades diarias, la primera es la de ordenar todos los productos de su pulpería, luego atiende de manera amable y cortes a todos sus clientes. Todos salen satisfechos por la calidad de productos y excelente atención que ella ofrece. Es una mujer inteligente y trabajadora, tiene 47 años y es madre soltera.  Hace tres años inició su negocio con un pequeño capital, sus conocimientos sobre administración de empresas le ha permitido mantener el negocio prospero y estable.  
Martha solicita el crédito para incrementar la producción de su trabajo, requiere comprar granos básicos tales como arroz y frijoles; también verduras, frutas, condimentos, pan, golosinas, refrescos, productos lácteos, entre otros. Ella deposita su confianza en el financiamiento puesto que logrará ofrecer variedad de productos, de manera que logrará ganar más clientela y obtener mejores ingresos. Uno de sus sueños es  que su negocio se transforme en una distribuidora. Asegura que luchara hasta lograrlo, su fuente de motivación son sus dos hijos, a quienes desea brindarle salud y educación de calidad.
texts.en:
Every morning, after having a cup of hot coffee, Martha starts her daily activities with a lot of energy. The first thing she does is sort the products in her grocery store, then she takes care of her customers in a kind and courteous way. All her customers leave the store satisfied by the quality of her products and the excellent attention she gives them.
Martha is an intelligent and hard working woman. She is 47 and a single mother. She started her business three years ago with a small capital and her knowledge of business administration has allowed her to maintain a profitable and stable business.
Martha is asking for a loan to increase her work production. She needs to buy basic grains such as rice and beans, and also vegetables, fruits, condiments, bread, assorted candy, beverages, dairy products, etc. She trusts that this loan will enable her to offer a variety of products so she can gain more customers and improve the profit. One of her dreams is to transform her business into a distribution center. She is determined to keep striving to reach that goal. Her motivation are her two children, for whom she wants to provide a healthy life and a quality education.

loans.use: to purchase basic grains such as rice and beans, and also vegetables, fruits, condiments, bread, assorted candy, beverages, dairy products, etc.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en: Mariam is a 53-year-old married woman from Senaki district, West Georgia. She lives with her husband, son and daughter-in-law. The family is involved in agricultural activities. In particular, they have cows and produce cheese. Mariam sells produced cheese at local markets. Her daughter-in-law works as a saleslady and gets a small monthly income. Mariam requested a loan of 3500 Gel to begin trading with clothing and bed-clothing. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo, enables her to get a loan. She plans to go to Turkey and purchase the products at wholesale prices and then resell among her friends and villagers. This will increase the family income and Mariam will provide better living conditions for her family. She awaits your support.

loans.use: to begin trading with clothes and bed-clothes.

loans.name: Sreyleap's Group

texts.en: Sreyleap’s group live in a rural village in Prey Veng province in Cambodia. Sreyleap makes a living cultivating rice and she also does extra work as a farm laborer to support her family. In their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. Having a water filter at home will help each of these women to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: To buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for their family.

loans.name: Van's Group

texts.en: Van’s group live in a rural village in Prey Veng province in Cambodia. Van makes a living cultivating rice and raising pigs to support her family. In their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water.  Having a water filter at home will help each of these women to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: To buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for their family.

loans.name: Abdulrahman

texts.en: Abdulrahman is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Abdulrahman joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Ya U, Lawal, and  Saidu. Abdulrahman is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Abdulrahman will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Abdulrahman can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to build a better home.” Abdulrahman is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “make more money for myself and my family”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick, age 48, lives in Chibombo, Zambia. He is asking for a loan so that he can obtain an additional water pump to help him irrigate and expand his garden crops.

Last season, Patrick obtained his first water pump from Rent to Own. He managed to grow watermelons, green peppers, tomatoes and onions. This season, he has big plans to expand his production further, and will need an additional water pump in order to keep up with the irrigation required during Zambia’s dry season.

Vegetable gardening is big business for many rural farmers in Chibombo District. Rent to Own has worked with Patrick on a business plan for this gardening season and will deliver a water pump directly to his farm. Rent to Own also provides Patrick with training on how to properly use and maintain the water pump, and will check in to provide support until he has paid off the loan.

With the water pump, Patrick is planning on growing watermelons and green peppers throughout the dry season, supplying local markets in Zambia’s capital city, Lusaka.

loans.use: to obtain a water pump for irrigation

loans.name: Radhika

texts.en:
Radhika is 50 years old. She is married and has two children aged 26 and 24. Many years ago, she established her tailoring business. Working seven days a week and eight hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid six loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent loan to buy raw materials for her business. In the future, Radhika plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support. 

 In the Kathmandu Valley, clothing is made to order. Tailor stalls line the streets where store owners sell material and work their sewing machines. These skilled tailors make school uniforms for children as well as the the traditional women's kurta surwal and men's daura surwal. With a Kiva loan, BPW borrowers are able to purchase additional cloth material or sewing machines that will increase production and profitability.

loans.use: to buy raw materials for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en:
Clarita is 48 years old and has five children. Clarita is married and has one child who is currently in school.

Clarita is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines. Clarita requested a PHP 27000 loan through NWTF to buy feeds, vitamins and vaccines for her business.

Clarita has been raising pigs for eight years now, and has borrowed eight times in the past from NWTF to sustain this business.

Clarita would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy feeds, vitamins and vaccines for her business.

loans.name: Milciades Lenin

texts.es:
Risas, gritos y bailes de alegría de niños cuando ganan un partido de futbol en videojuego es lo que complementa el negocio de Milciades, un hombre que se dedica al alquiler de videojuegos, para que tanto niños como jóvenes lleguen a entretenerse después de una jornada de clases. Es un hombre trabajador, tiene 41 años, está en unión libre y tiene un hijo. Hace diez años inició su negocio con el objetivo de mejorar la economía familiar, puesto que uno de sus ideales es que su familia goce un futuro prospero. Anteriormente ejercía la labor de zapatero en un taller, pero decidió independizarse y ahora está en la lucha  por seguir  progresando. 
Milciades solicita el crédito para incrementar la producción de su trabajo, requiere brindarle mantenimiento a los televisores y a las consolas,  al mismo tiempo, cambiar los controles, comprar más videojuegos, entre otros artículos.  Su meta es superarse, por lo tanto deposita su confianza en el financiamiento, con el que logrará captar más clientela e incrementar sus ingresos. Aparte del alquiler de videojuegos, se dedica a la reparación de electrodoméstico, sin duda alguna es un gran emprendedor. Agradece el apoyo de su familia, con la que la logrado salir adelante.
texts.en:
The laughter, yelling and dancing of happy children when they win in a soccer video game is what drives Milciades's business.  He is a man who works renting video games so that children and teenagers can entertain themselves after a day of school.  He is a 41 year old hard working man who is in a common-law marriage and has one son.

Ten years ago, he started his business with the goal of improving his family's financial situation.  One of his dreams is for his family to have a prosperous future.  Previously, he worked as a shoemaker in a workshop, but he decided to branch out on his own, and he now strives to get ahead.  

Milciades is seeking a loan to increase his work productivity.  He needs to repair the televisions and consoles, as well as change the controllers, and purchase video games and other items.  His goal is to improve, which is why he is placing his faith in this loan, which he hopes will allow him to attract more customers and increase his income.

In addition to renting video games, he also works repairing household appliances.  Without a doubt he is a great entrepreneur.  He is thankful for his family's support because it has allowed him to get ahead.

loans.use: to repair televisions and consoles, as well as change controllers, purchase video games and other items.

loans.name: Dative

texts.en:
Dative is aged 67 years old. She is married and her husband is a house builder.

She sells construction materials such as stones, sands and timbers, and she has spent 7 years in the business. With the loan, she would like to buy sands and stones for sale. The profits from the business will be used to make more savings, and she would like to own her vehicle in the future.

loans.use: to buy more sands and stones for sale

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida works hard to support her family. Zenaida is married and has a fish vending business in the Philippines.

Zenaida requested a PHP 12000 loan through NWTF to purchase more fish to sell to her customers.
