texts.fr: Le groupe de crédit Khelcom 4 est un sous groupe d’un réseau de femmes transformatrices de produits halieutiques. Il est composé de cinq femmes qui s’activent depuis plusieurs années et qui se sont regroupées pour bénéficier d’un appui financier qui leur permettra de renforcer leurs activités génératrices de revenus. Ngoné est la responsable du groupe, elle s’active dans la transformation de poisson frais en poisson séché. Elle a une expérience de plus de 10 ans. Le crédit lui servira à l’achat d’une charrette de poisson, qu’elle transformera elle-même car elle possède un mini puits (récipient qui sert à fermenter le poisson avant de le faire séché sur des séchoirs. Le produit fini sera vendu à sa clientèle du marché. Avec les bénéfices de la vente, elle appuie son mari dans les charges de la maison. Son projet futur est de construire sa propre maison.
texts.en:
The loan group “Khelcom 4” is a subgroup of a network of women who process seafood. The group is composed of five women, who have been active for several years and who have come together to benefit from financial support enabling them to bolster their revenue-generating businesses. 

Ngoné is the group’s official. She is active in producing dried fish from fresh fish. She has over ten years of experience. The loan will be used to purchase a cart of fish, which she will process herself, since she owns a mini-sink (a container used to ferment fish before drying them in drying devices). The finished product will be sold to customers at the market. With the profits from the sales, she supports her husband in covering household expenses. Her future plans include building her own house.

loans.use: to purchase fresh fish to process and sell

loans.name: Khelcom 8" Beug Manal Sa Bop" Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de crédit Khelcom 8 est un sous groupe d’un réseau de femmes transformatrices de produits halieutiques. Il est composé de cinq femmes qui s’activent depuis plusieurs années et qui se sont regroupées pour bénéficier d’un appui financier qui leur permettra de renforcer leurs activités génératrices de revenus. Khady est la responsable du groupe, elle s’active dans la transformation de poisson frais en poisson séché. Elle a une expérience de plus de 10 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de famille. Elle vient pour la première fois solliciter un crédit afin de pouvoir acheter du poisson, de le transformer en poisson séché pour le revendre.
Khady s’occupe de ses propres besoins et aide ses enfants en leur payant des cours particuliers, elle participe aussi à la dépense quotidienne.
Dans l’avenir, Khady veut diversifier son activité en faisant du commerce de denrées alimentaires et ouvrir une boutique.
texts.en:
The loan group “Khelcom 8” is a subgroup of a network of women who process seafood. The group is composed of five women, who have been active for several years and who have come together to benefit from financial support enabling them to bolster their revenue-generating businesses. 

Khady is the group’s official. She is active in producing dried fish from fresh fish. She has over ten years of experience and is a married mother of a family. She is here for the first time to request a loan  to be able to purchase fish for processing into dried fish to be resold.

Khady support herself and helps her children by cover their particular courses. She also helps in covering day-to-day expenses. For the future, Khady wants to diversify her business by doing commerce in grocery items and opening a store.

loans.use: to purchase fresh fish to commercialize

loans.name: Sopio

texts.en: Sopio is 27 years old. She is married and lives with her husband and two children. Sopio is unemployed and looks after her children. Her husband gets orders to work as a hire worker. Sopio decided to start a husbandry business and requested a loan. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo, enables her to get a loan of 1600 GEL to purchase a cow. When the cow is purchased she will start producing dairy products to sell locally. This will increase her family income. Sopio wants to expand the husbandry business in the future. The Start Up loan will be a great support for her family.

loans.use: to purchase a cow to start a husbandry business

loans.name: Sop Mame Diarra 7" Beug Manal Sa Bop" Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de crédit Sop Mame Diarra 7 est un sous groupe d’un réseau de femmes  commerçantes transformatrices de produits halieutiques. Il est composé de cinq femmes qui s’activent depuis plusieurs années et qui se sont regroupées pour bénéficier d’un appui financier qui leur permettra de renforcer leurs activités génératrices de revenus. La responsable, Fatou est mariée et mère de famille. Elle s’active dans le commerce de tissus, des ensembles pour enfants, hommes et dames depuis 7 ans ; elle gère aussi un restaurant où elle vend le petit déjeuner, le déjeuner et le diner. Avec le crédit, elle pourra acheter des tissus et aussi des condiments pour la préparation des mets qu’elle propose dans son restaurant.
Fatou participe activement dans la gestion de la dépense quotidienne. Elle désire ouvrir un grand magasin de ventes de tissus et produits cosmétiques.
texts.en:
The loan group “Sop Mame Diarra 7” is a subgroup of a network of women who process seafood. The group is composed of five women, who have been active for several years and who have come together to benefit from financial support enabling them to bolster their revenue-generating businesses. 

Fatou is the group’s official and a married mother. She has been active in the commerce of fabrics and outfits for children, men, and women for seven years; she also manages a restaurant, where she sells breakfast, lunch, and dinner. With this loan, she will be able to purchase some fabrics and also some condiments for making the meals offered in her restaurant. 

Fatou actively helps in managing day-to-day expenses. She wishes to open a large store for selling fabrics and cosmetic products.

loans.use: to purchase fabrics and outfits for children, men, and women to resell

loans.name: Bela

texts.en:
Bela is 27 years old. She lives in the small village of Senaki district with her husband, two daughters, and and grandfather, who is provided with a retirement pension. The family runs an agricultural business. In particular, they have cows and produce dairy products. In addition, they have a plot of land where nut trees are grown. They sell the harvested nuts at local markets. 

Bela wants to open a beauty salon and requested a loan. The Start Up Program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo, enables her to get a loan of 1,900 GEL to purchase all the needed equipment for becoming a hair stylist. She will offer her clients different kinds of services such as: hair cuts, hair dying, and so on. She is experienced in this field and thinks that the business will be profitable. Bela is very motivated and the Start Up Program will be a great support for her to fulfill her goals.

loans.use: to purchase all the needed equipment in order to open a beauty salon

loans.name: Tamta

texts.en: Tamta is 23 years old. She lives alone in the Kutaisi district. She works for the local building company as an operator. Tamta decided to start her own business and requested a loan. The Start Up Program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo, enables her to get a loan of $1,000 to purchase jewelry. She will purchase the stock at wholesale prices and then resell it at higher prices to generate profits. The Start Up Program will give her a chance to increase her income and with increased income, she will expand her business. Tamta awaits your support.

loans.use: to purchase different kinds of jewelry in order to resell them

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en: Caroline is a new client to the institution, she is married with children who attend school, and she comes from Kazindiro – Bugangari. Caroline does tailoring as her major source of income. She has done tailoring for a period of 10 years. Caroline has a market to serve but her major challenge is limited capital which affects her sales, Therefore, Caroline decided to join Ugafode for financial assistance to buy another sewing machine and more materials so as to serve the available market. Caroline hopes that the loan of 1,500,000 UGX can enable her to achieve her objectives and she thanks Ugafode for the support it extends to people.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine.

loans.name: Moshi Group

texts.en:
Josephina is in her late twenties and married, and together they are blessed with a baby girl. She has been supporting her family by managing a business selling women's and kids' shoes. She started this business three years ago. Josephina manages her enterprise and is able to get an excellent profit each month. She works three days a week (Friday, Saturday and Sunday) from 6 am to 7 pm.

This will be her first credit request via Tujijenge Tanzania. She will use this credit to replenish her business with new fashionable women's and kids' shoes. In the coming years, Josephina would like to grow her business more. She will share this loan with her loan group "Moshi" which consists of five members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to replenish her business with new fashionable women's and kids' shoes.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to improve his home

loans.name: Mkoani Group

texts.en:
Bertha is a mother of two children, a boy and a girl, one who is in school and another who is small. She is in her early thirties and married. Since 2008, Bertha has been running a beauty salon. She works from 8am to 8pm daily and is able to make a very good profit each month. 

The loan is from Tujijenge Tanzania, and this is her first loan request. She will use it to buy salon hair products to service more clients. She dreams of managing a shop selling cosmetics and hopes to live better. She will share this loan with her group "MKOANI" which consist of four members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy salon hair products to service more clients.

loans.name: Jesus Fernando

texts.en:
Jesus Fernando is 32 years old. He lives with his wife and a daughter that is 10 years old. He describes himself as responsible and hardworking. 

He is asking for a loan because he has been building his house, and he needs the money to finish it. Jesus Fernando owns a grocery store in which he sells different products like cream, cheese, packaged foods, snacks, sodas and other food products. He acquired the store five years ago and says that fortunately, he is doing ok, and the business has been growing. Occasionally, he also works as a waiter to earn extra income.

loans.use: to finish building his house.

loans.name: Lilly

texts.en: Lilly is a 44-year-old married woman with three children. She makes and sells ice cakes in her community to earn a living. She has two years of experience with this business. Lilly needs a loan to buy cordials, sugar, a large cooler, a chest freezer, foam cups and Chinese candy. She plans to use her profits to pay for her family's weekly expenses. Lilly has been a member of SPBD since 2014.

loans.use: to buy cordials, sugar, a large cooler, a chest freezer, foam cups and Chinese candy

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase yarn for weaving.

loans.name: Brenda Paola

texts.en:
Brenda Paola is 20 years old. She is married and has two small children. Her husband is a treat vendor. She produces plastic tarps, and her husband helps her with selling them. 

She is asking for a loan for the production of plastic tarps and bags. She says that by producing more, she can grow her business. She describes herself as credit-worthy, as in the past, she has taken some small loans and has always paid on time.

loans.use: to produce plastic tarps and bags.

loans.name: Siela

texts.en: Siela is a 28-year-old married woman with one child. She makes and sells pancakes in her community to earn a living. She has three years of experience with this business. Siela needs a loan to buy bags of flour, sugar, a large frying pan, a new oven, cooking oil, a strainer and yeast. She plans to use her profits to pay for her family's weekly expenses. Siela has been a member of SPBD since 2011.

loans.use: to buy bags of flour, sugar, a large frying pan, a new oven, cooking oil, a strainer and yeast.

loans.name: Omeka

texts.en: Omeka is a 57-year-old married woman with eight children. She makes and sells pancakes in her community to earn a living. She has six years of experience with this business. Omeka needs a loan to buy bags of flour, sugar, a large frying pan, a new oven, cooking oil, a strainer and yeast. She plans to use her profits to pay for her family's weekly expenses. Omeka has been a member of SPBD since 2008.

loans.use: to buy bags of flour, sugar, a large frying pan, a new oven, cooking oil, a strainer and yeast

loans.name: Malagamafaleupolu

texts.en: Malagamafaleupolu is 34 years old and married with four children. She has a small vegetable garden where she grows cabbages and tomatoes that she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for six years. Malagamafaleupolu needs a loan to buy insect poison, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gloves and a watering hose. She has been a member of SPBD since 2008. Malagamafaleupolu will use the profits from her sales to pay for her family's weekly expenses.

loans.use: to buy insect poison, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gloves and a watering hose.

loans.name: Pajo Metal Works Group

texts.en:
Paul is the group leader of Pajo Metal Works. He is 47 this year and happily married with five children. His children are 26, 20, 18, 14 and 8 years old, respectively. All five of them are currently attending school. Paul lives with his family in Cape Coast, the regional capital of the Central Region of Ghana.

Paul owns a welding company. He has been in business for the past 20 years. He is the founder of the company and has built the company up from scratch. Today, he has five permanent employees and more than 10 part-time workers. His company manufactures a whole range of products, including housing features and household appliances. His company is even able to remodel scrapped cars. 

Paul is beloved by the local community and has earned the endearing nickname "Opoman" for the Opoman canopy that he had invented. Prior to this invention, Ghanaians in his community used natural materials such as bamboo and palm leaves to build makeshift shelters for outdoor events such as funerals and soccer matches. These lacked structural integrity and did not provide adequate shelter in rain; in fact, when the rain came, people would abandon the shelter and run away! An extremely enterprising and creative man, Paul designed a cost-effective canopy comprising a metal framework with a waterproof canvas. This product was immensely well-received by consumers. Even then, he did not remain content with this breakthrough and has continually improved this product based on consumer feedback. He has since furnished the design with fluorescent light and electric fans, allowing these temporary shelters to provide not only safety, but also utility and comfort. 

Paul's most recent endeavor is the manufacturing of clean-cook stoves (a.k.a the Elsa Stove) that utilise waste-products, such as palm-kennel shells, as fuel. This stove is the product of a research project by the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) Group of States and sanctioned by the European Union (EU). He is now applying for a micro-loan to purchase raw materials such as metal plates, as well as the equipment needed for precise welding. Paul is very ambitious and excited about this product. He has secured an agreement with local distributors and plans to sell these stoves to consumers in the entire Central Region, and eventually expand the market to the whole country. Your loan will go a long way, not just in helping Paul achieve his ambitions, but also in providing Ghanians with a safer means of cooking that is free of indoor and outdoor pollution and reduces deforestation.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials and machines for manufacturing clean-cook stoves.

loans.name: Mala

texts.en: Mala is a 47-year-old woman, who is married with six children. She has a small lawn mowing business to earn an income. She has been in business for three years. Mala needs a loan to buy a new lawn mower, new spark plugs, a new pulling cord, new overalls, gloves and new gum boots. She will use her profits to pay for her family's weekly expenses. Mala joined SPBD in 2011 to gain access to financial services.

loans.use: to buy a new lawn mower, new spark plugs, a new pulling cord, new overalls, gloves and new gum boots.

loans.name: Edgardo Yoald

texts.es: Edgardo de 34 años de edad vive con su esposa y sus dos hijos,  es una persona responsable y muy trabajador, el posee una panadería ubicada en su lugar de residencia desde hace 17 años, elabora y vende repostería y pan francés, tiene mucha clientela por la amabilidad y los precios accesibles, con lo que el gana de sus ventas logra solventar las necesidades de su hogar, Edgardo solicita un crédito para la compra de harina, huevos, levaduras y más productos para la elaboración del producto, y asi poder obtener mejores ingresos y darle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Edgardo is 34 years old and lives with his wife and two children.  He is a responsible and hard working individual.  He owns a bakery which has been located in their residence for 17 years.

He makes and sells baked French bread.  He has a lot of customers because of his friendliness and affordable products.  His desire is to achieve sales enough to meet the needs of his household.

Edgardo is requesting a loan for the purchase of flour, eggs, yeast and other products for the manufacture of his products.  In this manner, he can get better income and give his family a better quality of life.

loans.use: to purchase of flour, eggs, yeast and other products.

loans.name: Mega

texts.en: Mega is 20 years old and unmarried with two children. She owns and operates a small store, selling a variety of items. She has been doing this for three years. Mega needs a loan to buy a new display fridge, a chest freezer, snacks, frozen goods, canned food, a sack of onions and potatoes. She hopes to use her profits to pay for the renovation of her house and help pay for her children's education. She became a member of SPBD in 2011 to gain access to capital for her business.

loans.use: to buy a new display fridge, a chest freezer, snacks, frozen goods, canned food, a sack of onions and potatoes.

loans.name: Mouena

texts.en: Mouena is a 46-year-old unmarried woman with four children. She runs a small bakery in her community to earn a living. She has two years of experience in this business. Mouena needs a loan to buy bags of flour, sugar, yeast, cooking oil, baking trays, icing sugar, butter and a large stove. She plans to use her profits to pay for her family's weekly expenses. Mouena has been a member of SPBD since 2012.

loans.use: to buy bags of flour, sugar, yeast, cooking oil, baking trays, icing sugar, butter and a large stove.

loans.name: Mataniu

texts.en: Mataniu is 42 years old and married with one child. She owns and operates a small store, selling a variety of items. She has been doing this for two years. Mataniu needs a loan to buy a new display fridge, snacks, frozen goods, canned food and sacks of onions and potatoes. She hopes to use her profits to pay for the renovation of her house and help pay for her children's education. She became a member of SPBD in 2014 to gain access to capital for her business.

loans.use: to buy a new display fridge, snacks, frozen goods, canned food, and sacks of onions and potatoes.

loans.name: Nora

texts.en: Nora is 38 years old and married with two children. She has a small plantation where she grows taro and bananas that she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for one year. Nora needs a loan to buy chemicals, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gumboots and a spade. She has been a member of SPBD since 2014. Nora will use the profits from her sales to pay for her family's weekly expenses.

loans.use: to buy chemicals, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gumboots and a spade.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en: Judith joined Paglaum MPC in the year 2007 and she appreciates the programs, services and continuous education of the co-op. She is a member in good standing and very active in attending the various programs and services that the Cooperative offers. She is requesting a loan in the amount of PHP 30,000 to pay for sari-sari store items. This loan is intended to purchase grocery items for her sari-sari store. Judith dreams of nothing more than to have a happy, healthy life and an adequate income out of her business.

loans.use: to purchase items for her sari-sari store.

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida is 52 years old and lives in Matugas Alto, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is married with three children now at their adult age. 

Leonida has been engaged in managing a sari-sari store that sells groceries and other consumable products for five years already, and earns approximately 1,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) each month doing this type of business activity. She has requested a loan to be used in purchasing additional stock of groceries and other consumable goods for retail.

Leonida has been a member of PMPC for three years. In the future, Leonida hopes to expand her sari-sari store business.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of groceries and other consumable goods

loans.name: Lilibeth

texts.en:
Lilibeth is 42 years old and lives in Sto. Niño, Pagadian City. She is married with two children.

Lilibeth has a tricycle and earns 15,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) each month doing this type of work. She has requested a loan to buy a new tricycle for the transport business.

Lilibeth has been a member of PMPC for seven years. In the future, Lilibeth hopes to have more tricycles for added income.

loans.use: to buy a new tricycle for the transport business

location.town: Pagadian-Sto. Nino, Pagadian City, Zamboanga Del S

loans.name: Mariche

texts.en:
Mariche, age 31, is from Bino-ongan, Enrique Villannueva, Siquijor, Philippines. She is married and is bravely aiming for many children. PMPC supported her by providing the capital to start her pig raising business. She sold one pig at a time, helping the family survive. She gives her best efforts to produce good pigs, in order to sell them continuously. 

Mariche is now trying to expand her pig business and has also decided to venture into a little restaurant. She presented her project proposal to Paglaum MPC to finance the project and has applied for a loan of PHP 5,000. She is thankful to Paglaum MPC for financing her capital needs. In addition, she wanted her business to be well known and to build a good business management for her loyal customers. With her extra income, she wishes to send all her children to school so they may have stable careers.

loans.use: to purchase feed and hogs for raising.

loans.name: Conception

texts.en: Conception earns a living through her fishing activities. She is adding another boat for fishing. She applied for a loan to pay for labor costs. Conception sells the fish caught by her husband, and she has doubled her income. She hopes to repay all her obligations so she has the assurance to apply for further assistance from the cooperative.

loans.use: to pay for labor costs

loans.name: Laura

texts.en: Laura is 39 years old and lives in Olingan, Dipolog City. In order to help the family, she sells food. Aside from selling food, specifically viands, she operates a sari-sari store. In 2006, she became an active member of Paglaum MPC with good credit standing. She wants to obtain financial assistance in the amount of 14,900 PHP (Philippines pesos) to purchase more goods for her sari-sari store, because selling viands is not sufficient for her daily needs. She already has a college student who wishes to help her in the near future.

loans.use: to pay for additional groceries for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina is 43 years old, married and lives at Olingan, Dipolog City, Zamboanga del Norte Philippines. In order to earn a living, she raises pigs on her own expense.

Through Paglaum MPC, she obtained the capital to purchase her original piglets and feeds. Now, she requests a loan of 5,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) to buy additional feed. She really hopes and prays that her business would grow and benefit her family, in addition to the income of her husband. Someday, she wants to build a concrete pig cage to easily keep more sanitary conditions.

loans.use: to pay for additional piglets and feed.

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel is 29 years old and lives in Dao, Pagadian City. She is married with two children.

Maricel has a sari sari (variety) store. She has had this business for 10 years. She requested a loan for her existing business.

Maricel has been a member of PMPC for six years. In the future, Marcel hopes to have an expansion.

loans.use: to buy additional items for her sari sari store

location.town: Dao Pagadian City Zamboanga Del Sur Philippines

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is married with four children. She is 43 years old and lives in Nazareth, Buenavista, Pagadian City.

Evelyn sells fruits and vegetables to earn a living and has been in business for five years. Evelyn requested a loan to buy fruits and vegetables to sell. She has been a member of PMPC for three years, and in the future, Evelyn hopes to have a large amount of capital to build a stall for display.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Sanavbarkhoni

texts.ru:
Эта молодая 23-летняя девушка по имени Санавбархони работает в ателье. Она профессионал своего дела. Вот уже 3 года как Санавбархони предоставляет услуги портнихи. Она шьет таджикские женские платья разных фасонов. Этому делу она училась в специальной школе портних. 
Санавбархони является уроженкой города Турсунзаде. Она еще не состоит в браке и живет с родителями и братом. Санавбархони целеустремленная девушка. Она сейчас хочет расширить свою деятельность. На сумму кредита Санавбархони собирается купить швейную машинку оверлок, а также другие необходимые швейные принадлежности. Она надеется на Вашу поддержку.
texts.en: This young, 23-year-old woman by the name of Sanavbarkhoni works at an atelier. She is a professional at her trade. Sanavbarkhoni has been providing seamstress services for 3 years already. She sews Tajik women's dresses of various styles. She learned this trade at a professional seamstress school. Sanavbarkhoni is a native of the city of Tursun-zoda. She is not yet married and lives with her parents and brother. Sanavbarkhoni is a goal-oriented young woman. She currently wants to expand her business. Sanavbarkhoni plans to use this loan to buy an overlock sewing machine and other sewing accessories. She hopes for Your support.

loans.use: to buy an overlock sewing machine and other sewing accessories

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay her tuition.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en: Teresita joined Paglaum MPC in the year 2012 and she appreciates the programs, services and continuous education of the co-op. She is a member in good standing and very active in attending the various programs and services that the Cooperative offers. She is requesting a loan in the amount of PHP 12,000. This loan is intended to purchase multicab spare parts. Teresita dreams of nothing more than to have a happy, healthy life and an adequate income out of her business.

loans.use: to buy multicab spare parts.

loans.name: Tiresa

texts.en: Tiresa is 56 years old and divorced with 2 children. She owns and operates a small flea market selling a variety of items. She has been doing this for one year. Tiresa needs a loan to buy samoan t-shirts, printed material, cava bowls, coconut carved earrings, bangles and samoan designed caps. She hopes to use her profits to pay for her family's weekly expenses and to help with the expansion of her business. She became a member of SPBD in 2014 to gain access to capital for her business.

loans.use: to buy samoan t-shirts, printed material, cava bowls, coconut carved earrings, bangles and samoan designed caps

loans.name: Selesa

texts.en:
Selesa is a 75-year-old widow with 10 children. 
She has a small farm where she raises chickens that she can sell in her community or to the public. She has been doing this for 2 years. Selesa needs a loan to buy barbed wire, timber, nails, iron poles, chicken food and some iron roofing sheets. She has been a member of SPBD since 2012. Selesa will use the profits from her sales to pay for her family's weekly expenses.

loans.use: to buy barbed wire, timber, nails, iron poles, chicken food and some iron roofing sheets

loans.name: Cherry Mae

texts.en:
Cherry Mae is 28 years old and lives in Dao, Pagadian City. She is married with 2 children.
Cherry Mae has a sari sari store. She has had this business for 4 years. She requested a loan to restock her store with consumable items.
Cherry Mae has been a member of PMPC for 4 years. In the future, she hopes to plan for an expansion.

loans.use: to restock her store with consumable items

loans.name: Tia

texts.en: Tia is a 57-year-old widow with 5 children. She runs a small barber shop business to earn a living. She has had this business for 7 years. Tia needs a loan to buy new hair clippers, scissors, hair gel, hair products, shaving cream, new chairs and a large mirror. She will use her profits to pay for her family's weekly expenses. Tia joined SPBD in 2007 to gain access to financial services.

loans.use: to buy new hair clippers, scissors, hair gel, hair products, shaving cream, new chairs and a large mirror

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en: Evangeline is a strong-willed woman who pushes her ability when it comes to selling. She is a hands-on businesswoman and mother who never gets tired of supporting her family. Recently, she took a loan to restock her store with consumable items. As well as her project of concreting her house,  she thought of raising pigs in her own backyard for extra income.

loans.use: to restock her store with consumable items

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en: Angelita has always dreamed of opening her own sari-sari store to support her family. She used her loan to buy sari-sari store inventories to sell. She is now on her way to repaying the loan with her new profits. She wishes to sustain her store and would love to open a bigger store outlet in the near future.

loans.use: To buy sari-sari store inventories to sell

loans.name: Aulafo

texts.en: Aulafo is a 32-year-old married woman with 5 children. She makes and sells barbeque in her community to earn a living. She has one year of experience with this business. Aulafo needs a loan to buy mutton flaps, chicken leg quarters, sausages, onions, soya sauce and tongs. She plans to use her profits to pay for her family's weekly expenses. Aulafo has been a member of SPBD since 2014.

loans.use: to buy mutton flaps, chicken leg quarters, sausages, onions, soya sauce and tongs

loans.name: Meripa

texts.en: Meripa is a 44-year-old married woman with six children. She makes and sells ice-pops in her community to earn a living. She has two years of experience with this business. Meripa needs a loan to buy cordials, small plastic bags, sugar, a large cooler and a mini chest freezer. She plans to use her profits to pay for her family's weekly expenses. Meripa has been a member of SPBD since 2014.

loans.use: to buy cordials, small plastic bags, sugar, a large cooler and a mini chest freezer.

loans.name: Suesa

texts.en: Suesa is a 25-year-old married woman with 2 children. She makes and sells barbeque in her community to earn a living. She has 4 years of experience with this business. Suesa needs a loan to buy mutton flaps, cases of chicken leg quarters, soya sauce, sausages and paper plates. She plans to use her profits to pay for her family's weekly expenses. Suesa has been a member of SPBD since 2010.

loans.use: to buy mutton flaps, cases of chicken leg quarters, soya sauce, sausages and paper plates

loans.name: Pyahu Group

texts.es:
Este grupo es nuevo, se formo en la ciudad de Curuguaty, una zona bastante alejada de la capital de país, eminentemente rural, que se encuentra aun en crecimiento.
La Sra. Nilda de es una de las integrantes, ella es de uno de los barrio de la ciudad donde tiene su pequeño negocio de Copetin Desea que conforme pase el tiempo, y por medio de las capacitaciones que pueda ir mejorando en su negocio para poder seguir ayudando a su familia.
Solicita de este préstamo para la compra de golosinas, galletitas, jugos, comestibles, y demás, para poder surtir su copetín con todo tipo de productos.
texts.en:
This is a new group. It is located in the city of Curuguaty, far from the capital of Paraguay, in an area which is very rural and is still developing. 

Nilda is one of the members of Pyahu Group. She lives in one of the neighbourhoods of the city, where she has her business, a small food counter and store. She hopes that over time, and with the training available to her, she will be able to improve her business and continue to support her family. She is seeking her portion of the loan in order to buy snacks, cookies, juices, foods, and other items, and so stock her food counter and store with all kinds of products.

loans.use: to buy snacks, cookies, juices, foods, and other items.

loans.name: Efremu

texts.en: Efremu remembers not being able to pay school fees  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Efremu, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Efremu  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 60 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family” expressed Efremu.   With this loan, Efremu is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Heribella

texts.en: Heribella is a hardworking mother and wife. She sells fish in the neighborhood to earn a living. This has supported her family for many years now. She would like to seek another loan to buy more kilos of fish to sell. Heribella dreams of positioning herself to become a fish dealer in the nearby towns.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Blandina

texts.en:
Blandina is 60 years old and lives in Centro Hulpa Tudela, Philippines. She is married with 3 children. 
To earn a living, Blandina has a business selling milk bars in the community. She earns about PHP 5000 each month doing this type of work. Blandina has requested a loan to provide additional capital for her milk bar business.

Blandina has been a member of PMPC for 2 months.  In the future, Blandina would like to provide for her family's daily needs.

loans.use: to provide additional capital for her milk bar business

loans.name: Iliya

texts.en: Iliya remembers not being able to pay school fees  during a particularly bad harvest. This is before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, as a Babban Gona member, Iliya like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the National average of 14. However, Iliya,  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 60 bags per hectare this season.  Iliya expressed that “In 5 years, I want to ensure other members of my community are lifted out of poverty.” With this loan, Iliya is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Samaila Daniel

texts.en: Samaila Daniel remembers not being able to feed his family  during a particularly bad harvest. This is before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, as a Babban Gona member, Samaila Daniel like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the National average of 14. However, Samaila Daniel,  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  Samaila Daniel expressed that “In 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family.” With this loan, Samaila Daniel is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en: In the year 2010, Francisca learned about Paglaum MPC and the financial assistance it gives start-ups. As a farmer in Balamban, Mahayag, she tried her luck and borrowed a loan to jump start her corn and rice production. After several months, she was able to return her borrowed capital. To this day, Francisca feels she owes her good fortune to the Cooperative for having trusted her with the money she used for her business. Recently, she availed herself of a loan to purchase farm inputs and fertilizer for the next cropping season. Francisca wishes to sustain her business and be able to supply corn and rice in the neighboring towns.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs and fertilizer.

loans.name: Lourygn

texts.en: Lourgyn landed at the right place for the capital she needed when she joined PMPC. She knew PMPC would be great for her business. She availed herself of a loan for the next crop season. She borrowed an amount for land and seedbed preparation.  Lourgyn perseveres and always believes in reaching her goals to continuously provide for her family.

loans.use: to pay for land and seedbed preparation

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en: Rosario landed at a right place for her needed capital when she joined PMPC. She knew this would be her chance to have a business. PMPC to Rosario came as a rescuer, lending her money when she needed it the most. Now, she has availed herself of another loan for the next cropping season. She borrowed an amount for land and seedbed preparation. Rosario perseveres and always hopes to reach her goals to continuously provide for her family.

loans.use: to pay for land and seedbed preparation.

loans.name: Marichel

texts.en:
In 2011, Marichel learned about Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative. She eagerly signed up for membership and tried her luck on starting a business focusing on her farming activities. 

Marichel has borrowed an amount to pay for seedlings and compost. This will help her farming income raise their family income. Marichel looks for better business opportunities and would love to be in the position to help others.

loans.use: to pay for seedlings and compost.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda learned about Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative and the financial assistance it provides to small-time borrowers like her. As a farmer in Balamban, Mahayag, she took out a loan to start her corn production.

After several months, she was able to return the amount she borrowed. Erlinda feels she owes her good fortune to the Cooperative for having trusted her with the money she used for her business. Recently, she availed herself of a loan to purchase farm inputs and fertilizer for the next crop season. Erlinda wishes to sustain her business and be able to supply rice in the neighboring towns.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs and fertilizer

loans.name: Bonifacio

texts.en:
Bonifacio is married with four children. Bonifacio is 57 years old and lives in Centro Napu, Tudela, Philippines. To earn a living, Bonifacio has a saw mill business. He has had this business for 10 years. Each month he earns approximately PHP 15,000. Bonifacio has been a member of PMPC for six years.
In the future, Bonifacio hopes to save for future consumption.

loans.use: to finance his saw mill business.

loans.name: Antoni

texts.en: Antoni is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Antoni joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Joshua, Sulemanu,  and   Atons. Antoni is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Antoni will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would  be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive, but are often diluted with external products like sand. With access to high quality inputs, Antoni can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14  and  earn up to $2000/ha, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked, Antoni said “I plan to use the money I make this year to provide more food and clothing for my family. Antoni is not thinking about just this year; he said, “in 5 years, I want to become the  most profitable farmer in my community.”

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita is married with four children. She is 55 years old and lives in Libertad Alto, Sinacaban, Philippines.

Anita is a farmer and grows corn crops to earn a living. She has been doing this for six years. She has requested a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides.

Anita has been a member of PMPC for nine years. In the future, she hopes to start another business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticides

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en: Emmanuel is a 47-year-old farmer from Rafin Tabo.  As a Babban Gona member, Emmanuel is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Emmanuel can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare,  double the national average of 14. However, Emmanuel is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make as a Babban Gona member, his said, “I plan to use the money to educate my children; Isuwa, Isiyaka, and  Adama. My overall goal is to become the most profitable farmer in my community.” With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving these goals.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Lily

texts.en: Lily is married with five children. Lily is 53 years old and lives in Pan-ay Clarin, Philippines. Lily is a farmer and grows rice crops to earn a living. She has been doing this for 10 years. She has requested a loan to buy eight sacks of fertilizer and insecticide. Lily has been a member of PMPC for 9 years. In the future, Lily hopes to put up other business.

loans.use: to buy eight sacks of fertilizer and insecticide.

loans.name: Vicky

texts.en: Vicky is married with two children and one of them goes to school.  She also takes care of additional family members. She sells fruits and vegetables and has been in this business for one year. She has applied for a loan of 200,000 Uganda shillings form MCDT-SACCO to buy tomatoes, oranges, pineapples, and onions. She gets additional income from selling pancakes at the market. She sells to all categories of people for seven days a week. Her major business challenges include seasonality and transportation.  She is aspiring to increase her sales to expand her business. She resides in a rented house and the family has access to electricity but not piped water.  Her monthly expenses include rent and school fees.

loans.use: To buy tomatoes, oranges, pineapples, and onions

loans.name: Gorretti

texts.en:
Gorretti is single with five children, two of whom go to school. She has no additional family members. She resides in a rented house, and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses includes school fees and feeding the family. Gorretti operates a kiosk at the market. She sells her products retail and wholesale. She has been in business for 14 years and she works seven days a week. 

Gorretti has applied for a loan of 2,000,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy sugar, rice, soap, biscuits, sweets, and cooking oil. Her major business challenges include seasonality and transportation. She aspires to have permanent premises for her business and to open another kiosk at the market.

loans.use: to buy boxes of biscuts, sweets, sugar, rice, and salt

loans.name: Joanitah

texts.en: Joanitah lives in Uganda, Kampala. She is single with one child and her child attends school. She also takes care of one additional family member. She sells fruits and vegetables from home. She operates her business on aretail basis. She works seven days a week .She has been in this business for two years. She has requested for a loan of Ugandan shillings 300,000 from MCDT – SACCO to buy oranges, onions, cabbages and tomatoes. Her major challenge includes transportation . Her goal and aspiration is to become a leading supplier of fruits and vegetables in her area of residence. She lives in a rented house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent and food.

loans.use: To buy boxes of tomatoes, onions, oranges, cabbages and radishs

loans.name: Singnat B Group

texts.en:
The featured borrower, Nemkhoman, with her hand raised, is 54 years old. She works very hard to support her family. She is blessed with four children, three boys and one girl. Being a single mother, she faces financial problems in raising her children with her profession as a cultivator. 
 
As daylight alone is not sufficient for her working hours, she needs the solar lighting system in her house. Solar lighting will allow her children to study late in the evening after sunset and do better in their studies. She also has a college-going child. She has high hopes that in the future, this child will become someone who can support the family. It shows that Nemkhoman is so much concerned about educating her children, which is one of the reasons for taking the solar loan. The lighting system will also help the featured borrower to perform her household chores swiftly after dawn and maintain a better study environment for her children.

The group Singngat B was formed by those women who have a common interest in getting a solar loan. The rest of the group members are engaged in weaving, vegetable vending and running a variety store.

loans.use: To buy a mini solar lighting system for household use and for her children to study for longer hours after sunset.

loans.name: Bengy

texts.en: In 2010, Bengy learned about Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative and the financial assistance it gives start-ups. As a farmer in Balamban, Mahayag, she tried her luck and took out a loan to jump-start her corn production. After several months, she was able to return the borrowed capital. To this day, Bengy feels she owes her good fortune to the Cooperative for having trusted her with the money she used for her business. Recently, she availed herself of a loan to purchase farm inputs and fertilizer for the next crop season. Bengy wishes to sustain her business and be able to supply corn in the neighboring towns.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs and fertilizer

loans.name: Emely

texts.en: In 2010, Emely learned about Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative and the financial assistance it gives start-ups. Emely tried her luck doing a business focusing on her farming activities. She feels she owes her good fortune to the Cooperative for having trusted her with the money she used as capital. Emely took out another loan to pay for seedlings and compost. This will give her farming income a big boost. Emely looks for better business opportunities and would love to be in a position to help others.

loans.use: to pay for seedlings and compost

loans.name: Jonlhing Group

texts.en:
Tingngaimoi (25) is the featured member of the group, Jonlhing, and is pictured with a raised hand. She lives in the outskirt village, which is ten kilometers from Churachandpur District headquarters of Manipur in the Northeast part of India. 

She is a businesswoman running a tea stall cum petty shop in her own house and sells items like daily essential products such as sugar, milk power, corn flour,  edible oil, cereal, eggs, can fish, biscuits, soap, toothpaste, detergent powder,fruit juice,betel nuts and leaves in the tea stall. She has been in this business since her mother passed away and has been the main source of income for the family since then. She has two younger brothers, whom she has been supporting in their education and other needs. Her father is a manual laborer with a very meager income. 

At her age, it is not easy to take responsibilities for the whole family and remain supportive to all the members. Tingngaimoi’s tea stall income is 15,000 INR per month. Tingngaimoi is in urgent need of money to upgrade her tea stall so that she can save money for her marriage in the near future.

The group, Jonlhing, was formed by women of common interest sharing similar economic background to get a loan. The loan will help them to buy inventory for their variety shops, which are the main source of income for their families.

loans.use: to purchase inventory including betel nut, sugar, milk power, corn flour,  edible oil, cereal, eggs, can fish, biscuits, soap, toothpaste, detergent powder, etc.

loans.name: Inocencia

texts.en:
Inocencia landed at the right place for the capital she needed when she joined PMPC. She knew PMPC would help her during the start-up of her business.

Inocencia is thankful that PMPC came to the rescue to lend her money when she needed it the most. Now, she has availed herself of another loan for the next crop season. She took out a loan for land and seedbed preparation. Inocencia perseveres and always believes in reaching her goals to continuously provide for her family.

loans.use: to pay for land and seedbed preparation

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma is a farmer who grows rice in Mahayag. She applied to PMPC for the capital she needed to start up her farming activities. She was happy to receive her first loans and the loans thereafter.

Norma took out another loan to buy seedlings and fertilizers for this crop season. She wishes to have a good harvest this time so she can renovate her house and save for emergencies.

loans.use: to buy seedlings and fertilizers

loans.name: Virgo Group

texts.en:
Nemhoi, 42, a featured member of the group Virgo with her hand raised, is a weaver by profession and earns a meager income. She lives with her father and brother. Her mother left them during her late childhood and she has been brought up in a difficult environment. Their total family income is 13,900 INR per month with Nemhoi being the main source of income. She makes 10,400 INR per month. The family has been living in a rented house and working in their own way to sustain their live. Nemhoi weaves different types of traditional shawls and wraparounds, namely Saipikhup and Khamtang(local name). She makes four to five products per month. She has been in need of money to buy yarn and weaving materials for better production of her products in the hope of a better income. The family has been planning to buy a small plot of land so that they can settle down in their own house for a better life. All members are working hard to save money to buy a plot and Nemhoi, being the main source of income, needs the loan as capital to improve her business.

The group Virgo was formed by women with a common interest to get a loan so that they can improve their business endeavors. The other group members are engaged in different businesses including retail shop and weaving.

loans.use: To purchase colorful patterns and varieties of yarn for weaving to generate more income.

loans.name: Maa Santosi Shg Group

texts.en:
Mamata is a 25-year-old lady who lives with her husband, parents-in-law and two children ages 5 and 2 years old in a small village in the Cuttack district in Odisha state, India. In the picture, the lady standing with her hand raised is Mamata. She is engaged in paddy cultivation. Her husband is doing the same business. Some years ago, Mamata formed a group with nine other women from her village and named the group "Maa Santoshi" self help group. All the group members are engaged in different business activities like selling milk, vegetable cultivation, etc to alleviate their poverty. 

Mamata is the president of this group. She motivated all the group members to form this group so they could help and support each other in their business and personal lives. Mamata, along with her group, requested a loan of 250,000 INR. She will use her portion to purchase standard quality seeds and fertilizers for her paddy cultivation. She hopes to build a house for her family and she is very grateful to Kiva for this opportunity.

loans.use: To purchase standard quality seeds and fertilizers for her paddy (rice) cultivation.

loans.name: Loom Group

texts.en:
Lhingneineng (32), the featured member of the group, shown with a raised hand, is a weaver by profession and is also very skillful in making clothes with a sewing machine. She lives in Churachandpur District of Manipur. Her parents left them during her adolescence, which was a painful memory for all of the siblings. She has been supporting her siblings since her elder brother got married and moved out to a different place. 

She weaves traditional shawls and wrap-around and sells them to generate income for sustaining the family. At present, she is trying to open a tailoring shop and needs capital for buying the machines. By doing so, she can employ two to three employees for her shop and generate more income and save more money to buy a plot of land. It is her long-desired dream to live on their own plot of land.

The group “Loom” was formed by women of similar interests to get a loan to make use of in improving their business endeavors. The other group members are engaged in retail shop and weaving businesses. All the members wanted to improve the financial condition of their own families and are in urgent need of money.

loans.use: to purchase a sewing machine, yarn and weaving materials to make more profits.

loans.name: Maa Mangala Shg Group

texts.en:
Sangita, aged about 20 years, is the group leader for the ten members of the group "Maa Mangala SHG" of Koraput district of Odisha state in India. Her family is composed of five members: herself, her husband, her parents-in-law and one child. 

The member seated second from the left is Sangita. She is a very active lady who wants some extra income from her own efforts. She has been running a grocery cum general store in her village with the support of her husband for the last two years. 

Sangita, along with the other nine members from her village, formed a group, and it is the first time they will take out a loan from People's Forum for development of their existing businesses. At present, her family income is about Rs. 5,000 per month, which is not sufficient to maintain her family. 

To improve her living conditions and to earn some extra income, she wants to access a loan. From the loan, she will purchase toothpaste, shampoo, detergent, soap, rice, edible oil, biscuits, sugar, etc., as general household items for resale. 

She has a dream: to build a house for her family. She is excited to have this loan, and she is very thankful to Kiva for this support.

loans.use: to purchase toothpaste, shampoo, detergent, soap, rice, edible oil, biscuits, sugar, etc, for resale.

loans.name: Maa Santoshi Shg Group

texts.en:
Sebati is a 32-year-old lady who lives with her husband, parents-in-law and three children in a small village in Odisha, India. In the picture, the lady standing with her hand raised is Sebati. She is engaged in paddy cultivation. Her husband is doing the same business. Some years ago, Sebati formed a group with nine other women from her village with the group name of "Maa Santoshi Self Help Group". All the group members are engaged in different business activities such as selling milk, vegetable cultivation, etc., to alleviate their poverty. 

Sebati is the president of this group. She motivated all the group members to form this group so they could help and support each other in their business and personal lives. Sebati, along with her group, requested a loan of 150,000 INR. She will use her portion to purchase standard-quality seeds and fertilizers for her paddy cultivation. She hopes to build a house for her family and she is very grateful to Kiva for this opportunity.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers for her paddy cultivation.

loans.name: Klara

texts.en:
Klara runs a small business. She used to sell cosmetics and other seasonal products. Due to her previous Kiva loan, Klara was able to increase her sales and earn additional income.

Recently Klara decided to change her business direction and began selling shoes. She found this business to be more profitable and wants to develop it. She is asking for a loan of 31,000 Ukrainian hryvnia (UAH) to increase the assortment of shoes she has for sale.

Klara is divorced. She lives with two children. She loves her family and her business, which is the only source of income for her family.

loans.use: to increase her assortment of shoes

loans.name: El Mana Group

texts.es:
La  asociación comunal el Mana está conformado por nueve integrante, casados con hijos menores de edad bajo su responsabilidad, personas originarias de una comunidad llamada santa rosa del peñón, son personas responsables, trabajadoras, con ganas de superación personal, lamentablemente por falta de recursos económico no pudieron estudiar y se vieron obligadas a trabajar desde temprana edad, para ayudar con los gastos del hogar. en la actualidad luchan día a día para brindarles a sus hijos un futuro mejor con oportunidades de estudios que ellos no tuvieron 
Gracias a su esfuerzo  y sus ganas de salir adelante los integrantes tiene diferentes actividad económica como pulpería, crianza de cerdos, venta de comida casera, un taller de soldadura, panadería. La coordinadora es  María del Rosario y tiene por actividad económica la elaboración y venta de comida casera en su casa de habitación, ella le vende a público en general y trabajadores de la zona. La rutina de trabajo de la Sra. María es de doce horas diarias, desde muy temprano se levanta a preparar los comestibles y cocina las diferentes platos como pollo frito, en caldo, arroz rellenos, maduros, indio viejos, empanadas, frijoles fritos etc.  El objetivo del crédito es invertir en la compra de productos comestibles para elaborar sus diferentes platillos y de esa forma poder mantener  obtener mejores ingresos y mantener sus clientes, a la vez cumplir sueños y metas establecidas como es preparar  a sus hijos darle educación y terminar su casa.  La asociación comuna El Mana agradece la ayuda que los inversionistas kiva le brindan a personas de escasos recursos y países pobre como es Nicaragua para tener un medio de trabajo digno.
texts.en:
The “El Mana” association is made up of 9 members who are married and have minor children in their care. They are from a community called Santa Rosa del Peñón and are known for being hardworking and responsible with a desire to personally succeed. Unfortunately they were not able to study for careers because they needed to go to work at a young age to help with the household expenses. Currently they are working hard to provide a better future for their children and an opportunity for them to get the education they did not have access to.  Thanks to their efforts and determination to get ahead, the members have different business activities such as a grocery store, raising pigs, selling food, a welding workshop, and a bakery.

The coordinator of the group is María del Rosario who sells home-cooked food from home to the public in general and workers in the area.  Her work schedule is 12 hours a day from very early in the morning when she gets up to prepare and cook the food.  This includes several different dishes such as fried chicken, chicken soup, rice, bananas, meat pries, fried beans, etc.  The aim of the loan is to buy ingredients for her food so she can earn more income and keep her clientele.  She also wants to meet her goals, such as preparing her children for an education and to finish her house.   The “El Mana” communal association is grateful for the help that the Kiva lenders provide to people of limited resources in poor countries such as Nicaragua, so that they can have a dignified source of work.

loans.use: To buy ingredients to make home-cooked foods such as fried chicken, chicken soup, rice, bananas, meat pies, fried beans, etc.

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en:
Estrella is from Calaca-an, Plaridel. She is a farmer who grows rice and corn. Estrella is a microfinance member and has availed herself of several loans from the Cooperative. Recently, she applied for a loan to buy seedlings and fertilizers.

Estrella owes the good return of her business to PMPC. She hopes to sustain her business and be able to buy more land to cultivate to expand her farming.

loans.use: To buy seedlings and fertilizers

loans.name: Isah

texts.en: Isah remembers not being able to pay school fees  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Isah, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Isah  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs” expressed Isah.   With this loan, Isah is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: San Rafael Group

texts.es:
Este grupo se encuentra trabajando de manera unida, están haciendo la encuesta de eliminación de la pobreza, con lo que quieren poder ir mejorando sus condiciones de vida.
Una de las integrantes es la Sra. Saturnina, quien se dedica a la venta de chipa, la cual es una comida típica paraguaya, comenta que por medio de su trabajo da a su familia todo lo que necesitan para una vida digna y sin privaciones, Saturnina es un ejemplo de lucha constante. Pide este préstamo para la compra de insumos para poder hacer las chipas que vende, como ser almidón, manteca, harina de maíz, huevos, queso y demás, y de esa manera seguir luchando por mejorar sus condiciones de vida y la de su familia.
texts.en:
This group is working together and taking part in the poverty elimination survey in an effort to improve their living conditions.

One of the members of the group is Saturnina who sells "chipas" (cheese buns), a typical Paraguayan food.  She says that through her work she is able to give her family everything they need for a decent lifestyle, and longing for nothing.  Saturnina is an example of constant struggle.

The loan she is requesting is to buy supplies to make the chipas she sells, such as corn starch, shortening, corn flour, eggs, cheese and other items.  This way she can continue striving for better living conditions for her and her family.

loans.use: To buy supplies to make chipa (cheese buns), such as corn starch, shortening, corn flour, eggs, cheese and other items.

loans.name: Saturnino

texts.es:
El señor Saturnino tiene 46 años de edad, está casado con la señora Mirian con quien tiene 3 hijos que aun van a la escuela, el matrimonio tiene como sostén de la familia una despensa bien surtida hace mas de 3 años, allí provee a vecinos y amigos de todo tipo de insumos de primera necesidad para el hogar como carne, verduras, carbón, yerba, artículos de limpieza, lácteos, carbón, bebidas en general, embutidos y otras insumos básicos.
El señor Saturnino solicita el préstamo para la compra de diversos insumos para la despensa como ser lácteos, carbón, bebidas en general, embutidos y otros, ya que desea aumentar su stock de productos a modo de generar mayores ventas y obtener mejores ingresos familiares. Agradece a Fundación Paraguaya y a Kiva por la oportunidad recibida.
texts.en:
Saturnino, 46, is married to Mirian and they have three school-aged children.  The family earns a living running a well-stocked store that they have had for three years.  They supply their neighbors and friends with all kinds of basic essentials for the home such as meat, vegetables, coal, tea, cleaning products, dairy products, drinks in general, sausages and other staple goods.

Saturnino is requesting a loan to buy a variety of supplies for his store such as dairy products, coal, drinks in general, sausages, and other items.  He wants to increase his stock to generate more sales and earn more income for the family.  He is grateful to Fundación Paraguaya and Kiva for this opportunity.

loans.use: To buy dairy products, coal, drinks in general, sausages, etc.

loans.name: El Aguacate  (Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El grupo de crédito El Aguacate está formado por un grupo de 8 mujeres y 4 hombres quienes trabajan en diferentes actividades con un solo propósito que es salir adelante con sus familias, viven en la comunidad del Aguacate en la ciudad de Cuenca, esta ciudad es reconocida por su belleza arquitectónica, sus paisajes, su gastronomía y por su gente que es cálida y amable.
Una de las socias de este grupo es la Señora. Verónica, está realizando su primer crédito en el grupo de crédito El Aguacate ya que quiere crecer en su negocio.
La Señora. Verónica tiene 27 años de edad, vive en unión libre y ha concebido 3 hijos de 7, 4 y 2 años, su primera hija estudia en la escuela, su esposo trabaja en la elaboración de cielos rasos, la casa en la que vive es  propia.
Doña Verónica se dedica a los quehaceres de su hogar y al cuidado de sus hijos, pero para aportar en la economía de la casa se dedica  a la cría de pollos. Su crédito es para la compra de pollos y hacer un galpón de pollos más grande. Su meta es ampliar su casa.
texts.en:
The communal bank El Aguacate consists of eight women and four men who work in different business activities with one objective which is to get ahead with their families.  They live in the community of Aguacate in the city of Cuenca which is known for its beautiful architecture, scenery, gastronomy and warm, kind people.

One of the members of the group is Verónica who is taking out her first group loan since she wants to expand her business.

Verónica, 27, lives with her common-law husband and their three children, ages 7, 4 and 2.  Her eldest daughter attends school and her husband works in construction (ceiling work).  They own the house they live in.

Verónica is in charge of the housework and takes care of the children, but she also contributes to the household economy by raising chickens.  The loan she is requesting is to buy chickens and to build a larger chicken coop.  Her goal is expand her house.

loans.use: To buy chickens and build a chicken coop.

loans.name: Samet's Group

texts.en: Samet, a villager from Koh Sotin district of Kampong Cham province, Samet is 49 years old and married. He is a father of three kids. He earns a living rice cropping and through his occupation at a garment factory. This business generates him about 28,900 KHR per day. Samet is a first-time borrower with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). Now, he joins a group of two to get a new loan. As the leader, he will spend his entire loan portion to buy a decent motorbike to support his business and to buy fertilizer for his crop. He hopes to gain a better yield than before.

loans.use: to buy a decent motorbike to support his business and to buy fertilizer for his crop.

location.town: Prey Veng Province, Sithor Kandal district

loans.name: Vantin's Group

texts.en:
Vantin, 40, is married and lives with her husband and three children in a village of the Moung Russey district of Battambang province. She and her husband have been selling eggs and working as paid construction workers. They have been in this business for three years. 

Vantin has been with VisionFund for one cycle and completely paid back the past loan. Now she is requesting another loan from VisionFund. Vantin, who is the leader, will use her portion to buy more eggs for resale. She hopes to make more income from her current business.

loans.use: to buy more eggs for resale.

loans.name: Rabo

texts.en: Rabo remembers not being able to feed her family  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before she became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Rabo, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Rabo  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family” expressed Rabo.  With this loan, Rabo is well on her way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Munkaila

texts.en: Munkaila is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Munkaila joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Fatsima, Abdulrazaku, and  Abdulrau,. Munkaila is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Munkaila will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Munkaila can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Munkaila is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Abdulhamidu

texts.en: Abdulhamidu is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Abdulhamidu joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children:  Aaliyah, Nanah,and Umaira. Abdulhamidu is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, he will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, Abdulhamidu, would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products like sand. With access to high quality inputs through this Babban Gona loan, Abdulhamidu can reap 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14  and  earn up to $2000/ha, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked, Abdulhamidu said “I plan to use the money I make this year to provide more food and clothing for my family." However,  Abdulhamidu is not thinking about just this year; he  said,  “In 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community.”

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Virginia Eloy

texts.es: Virginia de 61 años de edad es una persona humilde y trabajadora, vive en casa propia con su esposo, desde hace varios años se dedica a la elaboración y venta de tortillas, su negocio lo tiene ubicado en su lugar de residencia, en una zona muy transitada por esa razón posee mucha clientela, con lo que obtiene de su trabaja y con ayuda de su esposo logran salir adelante, Virginia está solicitando un crédito para la compra de  maíz por quintales y cal, para seguir con la elaboración de las tortillas y así poder tener junto con su esposo una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en: Virginia is 61 years old and a humble and hard-working person. She lives in a house that she owns with her husband. For a number of years Virginia has made a living producing and selling tortillas from her business that she runs out of her home. Virginia's business is in an area with many passers-by and so she has many customers. With profits from her work, and with the help of her husband, the couple is getting ahead in life. Virginia is applying for a loan in order to buy corn by the hundredweight, and lime. These items will allow Virginia to continue to make tortillas and she can enjoy a higher quality of life with her husband.

loans.use: to buy corn by the hundredweight, and lime.

loans.name: Buena Esperanza Group

texts.es:
La asociación comunal Buena Esperanza está conformado por nueve integrantes, madres solteras, responsables de sus hijos. Son originarias del Sauce. Se caracterizan por ser trabajadoras, responsables con ganas de superación personal.  Estas madres luchadoras, lamentablemente no pudieron estudiar, por falta de recursos económicos, desde muy joven  trabajan para ayudar con los gastos de su hogar.
 En la actualidad, gracias a sus esfuerzos y sus ganas de salir adelante tiene diferentes actividades económicas como destace, crianza de cerdos, venta ropa, pulpería, venta de cosa de horno.  La coordinadora es  Eva Luz, y tiene por actividad económica la venta de cosa de horno es su casa de habitación y de forma ambulante, esta mujer dedica a su negocio unas  doce horas diarias, ofreciendo el mismo la rutina de trabajo de Eva es viajar todos los días a las  ciudades principales para ofrecer  la cosas de horno se levanta muy temprano para tomar el auto bus de su comunidad a la ciudad con una pana de unos  treinta kg diariamente, actividad que la realiza con mucho gusto porque ha sido la forma de vida para su familia.  El objetivo del crédito es invertir en capital de trabajo y surtir su venta de cosa de horno para en un futuro no muy lejano obtener mejores ganancias, y mantener la clientela.  La asociación comunal Buena Esperanza agradece la ayuda que los inversionistas kiva ofrecen a personas de escasos recursos y países pobre como es Nicaragua  para tener un medio de vida digno.
texts.en:
The communal bank Buena Esperanza consists of nine members who are single mothers, responsible for their children.  They are from the Sauce region.   These hard-working women were unable to get an education because they had to go to work very young to help with household expenses.

Now, thanks to their efforts and determination to get ahead, they work in different business activities such as butcher, raising pigs, clothing sales, a grocery store, baked goods sales.

The group coordinator is Eva Luz who sells baked goods that she makes at home and sells as a street vendor.  She dedicates 12 hours a day to her business activity and travels every day to major cities to offer her goods.  She gets up early in the morning to take a bus to the city, carrying 30 kgs of goods.  She enjoys her work because it is what her family did.

The loan will be used to buy baking goods so in the near future she can earn more profit and keep her clientele.  The Communal Bank is grateful to the Kiva lenders for providing assistance to people who have limited resources and come from poor countries, such as Nicaragua, so that they are able to make a decent living.

loans.use: To buy baking goods.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.es: El cliente de 25 años de edad se dedica a la agricultura desde hace algunos años, su principal siembra es el maíz, comercializa sus productos en los alrededores de la zona, con lo que obtiene de sus ventas ayuda a su familia en los gastos del hogar, vive en casa propia con la madre, la esposa y el hermano, el cliente se acerco a la institución de INTEGRAL para solicitar un crédito para la compra de semillas, fertilizantes, abonos, controles de plagas, herbicidas, etc. y mejorar el terreno  que muestra en la fotografía para poder continuar con sus cultivos y darle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en: This borrower is 25 years old. He has been working in farming for a few years. His main crop is corn. The borrower sells his products in the surrounding areas. With profits from sales, the borrower helps his family with household costs. This borrower lives with his mother, his wife and his brother in a house owned by the family. He has come to "Apoyo Integral" in order to apply for a loan that will be used to buy seeds, fertilisers, manure, anti-disease treatments, weed-killers and more, and to improve his land (shown in the photograph). With this loan, the borrower can continue to grow crops and offer his family a higher quality of life.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilisers, manure, anti-disease treatments, weed-killers and more, and to improve his land.

loans.name: San Francisco De Asis Group

texts.es: La Sra. Cristel es separada y tiene 3 hijos, los cuales ya no dependen de ella. Lleva 8 años como cliente de Edaprospo y se dedica al servicio de transporte ya que tiene 2 autos los cuales da en alquiler. Ella inicio este negocio por motivación propia y de su familia, ya que el ingreso que percibía únicamente era el de su esposo, el cual no le era suficiente para cubrir todos sus gastos y necesidades;  es así que decidió emprender este pequeño negocio que le ayudó mucho para así poder brindarles una mejor calidad de vida a sus hijos. Con su esfuerzo y trabajo, Cristel ha logrado cubrir algunos gastos que tiene en su hogar tales como alimentación, vestimenta y los pagos de servicios. Su plan familiar para el futuro es que sus hijos tengan su propia empresa, y el de su negocio es adquirir más autos para continuar con la expansión del servicio de transporte. Ella utilizó el préstamo en el mantenimiento de sus autos. Cristel pertenece a la alcancía comunal “San Francisco de Asís”, el cual está conformado por 7 socios y en donde ocupa el cargo de presidenta. Ella se encuentra de pie en la parte del medio con una chompa de color morado.
texts.en:
Cristel is separated and has three children who are no longer dependent on their mother. Cristel has been a customer as "Edaprospo" for eight years and works in transport. She has two cars that she rents out. Cristel started this business when motivated by her family and on her own. Previously her only income was that of her husband and this was not enough to pay for all expenses at home. As a result Cristel decided to start this little business that helped her greatly to provide her children with a better quality of life.
