With effort and hard-work, Cristel has been able to cover some household costs, such as food, clothing, and utility bills. In the future Cristel would like her children to have their own business. At her business, Cristel would like to own more cars in order to expand her transport services.

Cristel will use this loan to pay to maintain her cars. Cristel is a member of the "San Francisco de Asis" (Saint Francis of Assisi, in English) communal bank. Cristel is president of this group, which has seven members. In the photo, Cristel is in the middle; she is standing up and wearing a purple jacket.

loans.use: to maintain her vehicles.

loans.name: Alh. Lawal

texts.en: Alh. Lawal is a farmer from Nasarawa.  As a Babban Gona member, Alh. Lawal is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Alh. Lawal can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Alh. Lawal is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to access quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least 50 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Alh. Lawal is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children; Abdul,  and Abubakar. Alh. Lawal’s dreams do not end there: “ultimately, I want to make more money for myself and my family”, he expressed.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Halladu

texts.en: Halladu is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Halladu joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Safiya, Ummaru, and  Zaharau,. Halladu is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Halladu will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Halladu can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Halladu is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim remembers not being able to pay school fees  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, Ibrahim, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Ibrahim is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. “In 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs,” expressed Ibrahim. With this loan, Ibrahim is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Lawal

Like all Babban Gona members, Lawal can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Lawal is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to acces quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least 35 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Lawal is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children; Matayas,and  Inusa. Lawal’s dreams do not end here: “ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”, he expressed.

loans.name: Malama

texts.en: Malama remembers not being able to feed her family  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before she became a Babban Gona Member. Now, Malama, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Malama is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.    “In 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family”, expressed Malama . With this loan, Malama is well on her way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Angela  Vilma

texts.es: Ángela de 61 años de edad es una persona muy trabajadora y responsable, siempre está buscando la manera de darle a su familia lo mejor, hace 14 años decidió poner en su hogar una pequeña tienda que le ayudara a salir adelante con los gastos, y es asi como logro salir adelante, tiene mucha clientela por la variedad de productos que comercializa, Ángela vive en casa propia con su esposo, ella está solicitando un crédito para poder comprar mercadería como: frijoles, golosinas, azúcar, arroz, refrescos, jabón, papel higiénico etc. todo por mayor  y poder atender mejor a sus clientes, y así junto a su esposo tener una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Ángela, 61, is a hard-working, responsible person who is always seeking ways to give her family the best she can.  Some 14 years ago she decided to set up a small store in her house to help get ahead and cover expenses.  She has many customers because of the variety of products she sells.

Ángela lives in her own home with her husband.  She is requesting a loan to buy more merchandise such as beans, sweets, sugar, rice, soft drinks, soap, toile paper, etc. on a wholesale basis.  This is so she can provide better customer service and, together with her husband, enjoy a better quality of life.

loans.use: To buy wholesale goods, including beans, sweets, sugar, rice, soft drinks, soap, toilet paper, etc.

loans.name: Maria Iveth

texts.es: Maria de 31 años de edad es madre soltera vive en casa propia con sus hijos, ella se dedica a la venta de carteras, vende de forma ambulante por las diferentes colonias y mercados que se encuentran cerca de su lugar de residencia, con lo que obtiene de sus ventas logra solventar los gastos que se le presenta en su hogar, Maria está solicitando un crédito para la compra de variedad de carteras por mayor para poder seguir con su negocio y poderle dar a sus hijos una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en: María is 31 years old and a single mother. She lives with her children in a house that she owns. María makes a living selling handbags as a street vendor. She works in the areas and markets near her home. With profits from sales María is able to cover household costs. María is applying for a loan in order to buy a variety of handbags in bulk. With these items María can continue with her business and offer her children a higher quality of life.

loans.use: to buy a variety of handbags bulk.

loans.name: Bitrus Gogarma

texts.en: Bitrus Gogarma is a 40-year-old farmer from Gogarma.  As a Babban Gona member, Bitrus Gogarma, is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Bitrus Gogarma can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare,  double the National average of 14. However, Bitrus Gogarma is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. When asked, Bitrus Gogarma said “I plan to use the money I make to educate my children; Mallakai, Kathrine,  and  Cicilia, and in 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Ishaku

texts.en: Ishaku is a maize farmer from Gogarma.  As a Babban Gona member, Ishaku , is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Ishaku can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare,  double the National average of 14. However, Ishaku is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. When asked, Ishaku said “I plan to use the money I make to educate my children; Jonathan, Nahemiya,  and  Macy, and in 5 years, I want to ensure other members of my community are lifted out of poverty”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Saminu

texts.en: Saminu is a Babban Gona farmer from Gogarma. Saminu is driven by one goal: to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is this ambition that led Saminu to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Saminu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Saminu is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season because with this loan, he will finally be able to access the required yield enhancing inputs such as improved seeds. Saminu is hoping that as a result of this expected yield, he will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what changes he would like to make, he said “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland.  Ultimately, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community.” With this loan, Saminu will be able to access all the inputs and services to make these dreams reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Ishaya

texts.en: Ishaya is a Babban Gona farmer from Mai Kyau. Ishaya expressed that he is driven by one goal: to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Ishaya to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Ishaya can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Ishaya is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 40 bags per hectare this season. By doing so, Ishaya will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what he plans to do with his income from this season, he said: “I plan to use the money I make to provide more food and clothing for my family”. With this loan, Ishaya will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Maa Manikeswari Shg Group

texts.en:
Maa Manikeswari Self Help Group (SHG) was formed in January 2014 and consists of 13 rural poor women belonging to the below-poverty-line category. This group is located in a remote rural village in the Kalahandi district of Odisha, India. Vegetable cultivation and vending is the primary source of livelihood for most of the members of this group. 

Satyabhama is one of the members. The lady seated in the middle is Satyabhama. She is a very active lady, 41 years of age. She lives with her husband, one son and one daughter. Satyabhama has a vegetable cultivation farm on one hectare. She and her husband manage the farm. Her husband is an active and cheerful farmer. They produce vegetables like brinjal (eggplant), cauliflower, carrots, cabbage, chilies, cucumbers, papaya, lady’s finger (okra), onions, etc. on the farm. She sells her products to the traders from the nearest town who come to take vegetables from her farm. Satyabhama says that she earns a minimum of 5,000 INR per month from this business. This is insufficient to meet the day-to-day expenses of her family as well as the farm expenses. Satyabhama wants to expand her business by taking a loan from People's Forum. She will use the present loan to buy fertilizer and farm inputs such as seeds and pesticides for her farm. She expects a good return from her business by expanding her cultivation. Satyabhama dreams of constructing a house and purchasing a water pump for a better irrigation facility for her farm. She also hopes to give her whole family a bright future through her hard work. The other members of this group are also involved in businesses like vegetable cultivation, a general grocery shop, vegetable vending, and tailoring businesses.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and farm inputs such as seeds and pesticides

loans.name: Nila Maa Shg Group

texts.en:
This group, called "Nila Maa Shg", consists of 14 ladies who live in a small village in the Koraput district of Odisha, India. The group has applied for a loan of 210,000 INR from People's Forum (Kiva's Partner). All the members of this group are involved in different livelihood activities like animal raising, vegetable selling, milk selling etc. 

Rina (the lady seated in the middle), a 38-year-old married mother with one son, has been working as a vendor selling fish and other foods such as items made of milk. She started her business with a small amount of capital and would now like to increase her sales volume in order to increase her profit and raise her son well. She has requested a loan to purchase more fish and other food (milk). Rina hopes to expand her business to live comfortably with her family. She, along with her group members, is very excited and grateful to Kiva and its lenders across the world for this kind help and support.

loans.use: to purchase more fish and milk for her food business.

loans.name: Bol's Group

texts.en: A citizen from Bovel district of Battambang province, Bol is 45 years old and married. He has three dependent children, all of whom remain in school. To struggle for a living, he grows rice and chili as the main source of income and works for others for a fee for extra income. This is not a new loan for Bol with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). He has fully repaid his past loan and he can improve his lifestyle gradually. Now, in a group of two, he leads the group to get a new loan. As the leader, he will spend his entire loan portion to pay plowing fees for his crop. He hopes to gain a better yield than before.

loans.use: To pay for plowing fees for his crop

loans.name: Heang's Group

texts.en: A local farmer from Bovel district of Battambang province, Heang is 45 years and married. She overcomes her family's hardships via rice farming, cassava planting, and pig-raising businesses as her main source of income. She has been involved in her current businesses for ages. This is the first loan for Heang with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). Now, she leads a group of two to get a new loan. As the leader, she will spend her entire loan portion to buy pig feed and to make pigpen. She hopes to gain a better job than before.

loans.use: To buy pig feed and make a pigpen

loans.name: Samaila

texts.en: Samaila is a 23-year-old farmer from Sarki.  As a Babban Gona member, Samaila is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Samaila can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Samaila is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to acces quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least 35 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Samaila is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children:  Salina,  Nabon,  and  Precious. Samaila’s dreams do not end here: “ultimately, I want to ensure other members of my community are lifted out of poverty”, he said.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Chhun

texts.en:
Living in a wooden house located in the Ou Reang Ov district of Kampong Cham province, Chhun is 60 years old and married. She has two children. To make a living, she and her husband have been farming rice for 42 years and they supplement the family’s income by working for others for a fee. The current business earns them about US $15 per day. They manage to save about US $13 each day for their future needs.
 
This is the first micro loan for Chhun with VisionFund. Now she is applying for a loan to renovate her old house (bricks, doors, etc.) She hopes to have a decent house to live in.

loans.use: to renovate her old house

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ou Reang Ov district

loans.name: Chreb

texts.en:
Chreb is 35 years old and married with three children. She lives in a rural village of the Kampong Cham district where crop farming is a common way to make a living. Like other villagers, rice farming and cassava growing have been her family’s main source of income for nine years.
 
Chreb has been with VisionFund for six cycles and now she is seeking a loan to pay for fertilizers for her farmland. She hopes to grow her rice and cassava fruitfully and healthily in order to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: to pay for fertilizers for her farmland

loans.name: Ra

texts.en:
Ra is 32 years old and married. She is a mother of four children. To make a living, she and her husband have been farming rice and growing cassava for 13 years and supplement their family’s income by selling grocery items. The current business earns her about 27,000 KHR per day to support her family. 

This is the first loan for Ra with VisionFund. Now she is applying for a loan to buy fertilizers and seeds for her farmland. She hopes this loan will enable her to increase her crop yield to make a better living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and seeds for her farmland

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Tbaung Khmum district

loans.name: Sokhom's Group

texts.en: Originally from Thmor Koul district of Battambang province, Sokhom is 33 years old and a widow. She is a mother of two kids; one is in school and one is too young for schooling. For the sake of her family, sesame farming is the main source of her income. This is not the original loan for Sokhom with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). The positive impact of her past loan allows her to improve her lifestyle at a gradual pace. Now, she joined a group of four to get a new loan. As the leader, she will spend her entire loan portion to buy herbicide and fertilizer for her crop. She hopes to gain a better yield than before.

loans.use: to buy herbicide and fertilizer for her crop

loans.name: Bitrus

texts.en: Bitrus is a 33-year-old farmer from Sarki.  As a Babban Gona member, Bitrus, is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Bitrus can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Bitrus is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to acces quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least  35 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Bitrus is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children; Mercy,  and  Zainab. Bitrus’s dreams do not end here: “ultimately, I want to make more money for myself and my family”, he expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Murtala

texts.en: Murtala is a Babban Gona farmer from Sarki. Murtala expressed that he is driven by one goal: to “ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Murtala to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Murtala can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Murtala is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season. By doing so, Murtala will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what he plans to do with his income from this season, he said: “I plan to use the money I make to build a better home”. With this loan, Murtala will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Maria Rosalba

texts.es:
Maria, a sus 59 años de edad, es una mujer trabajadora y pujante; pues siempre va en busca de alternativas que le permitan progresar. 

Desde hace muchos años se dedica a trabajar en el campo de la confección, el oficio lo aprendió de manera empírica por medio de la observación, poco a poco fue perfeccionando su técnica y ampliando sus conocimientos por medio de la práctica.
Esto la impulsó para iniciar su propio taller, para lo cual adecuó un espacio en la casa donde reside y con unos ahorros que tenía compró sus primeras máquinas.
Trabaja sola todos los días, pero en ocasiones recibe el apoyo de una persona, dependiendo de la cantidad de contratos que tenga
De esta forma ha logrado generar los recursos suficientes para solventar los gastos del hogar. 

El crédito que solicita es un apoyo para el fortalecimiento de su labor, pues con el dinero comprará una máquina fileteadora y una recubridora, con las que podrá agilizar el proceso de producción y adquirir más contratos, generando mayor rentabilidad en el negocio. 

Maria manifiesta que su mayor desafío es la competencia en el mercado, sin embargo esto la sigue motivando para seguir prestando un mejor servicio y luchar para que el sueño de la acreditación de su negocio se haga realidad y le permita generar oportunidades de empleo, así mejorará su calidad de vida y la de las personas que influyan en la labor.
texts.en:
Maria is 59 years old and is a hard-working and thriving woman. She always looks for alternatives that will allow her to grow.  

For the past several years she has worked in the field of sewing, a skill that she learned empirically by observation and that little by little she has been perfecting, expanding her knowledge and honing her technique through practice.  

This has motivated her to open her own shop, for which she prepared a space in her home.  With some savings she bought her first machine. She works alone every day, but on occasion she receives help from someone depending on the quantity of the contract that she gets.  In this way she has been able to generate enough income to pay for household expenses.  

She is asking for a loan in order to strengthen her work, since with the money she will buy specialized sewing machines which will make her work more rapid and facilitate production and the acquisition of more contracts, generating more income. 

Maria states that her greatest challenge is competition in the market.  However, this keeps her motivated to offer better service and to struggle so that her dream of having an accredited business will become reality and that will generate more opportunities for work. In this way she will improve her quality of life as well as the quality of life for others who work with her.

loans.use: To purchase specialized sewing machines.

loans.name: Sokunthea's Group

texts.en:
Sokunthea, 34 years old, is a married mother of three children living in a rural village of the Dambae district, Cambodia. To support her family, Sokunthea has been farming rice and planting cassava for 25 years in the village. The current business earns her about 26,500 KHR per day. 

She has been with VisionFund for six cycles and now she is leading her group to seek a loan. As the leader, she is going to use her portion to buy fertilizers and seeds for her farmland and use a portion of it to spend for land plowing. She hopes to increase her crop yields and sell the crops for a good price to make a better living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and seeds for her farmland

loans.name: Savet's Group

texts.en: A local resident from Battambang province, Savet is in her early 50s and a mother of three children. She secures the basic need of her family via rice cropping on two hectares and her paid working job. She has been involved in her current business for 10 years. For ages, she has been involved with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). She has fully repaid her past loan. Now, she teams up in a group of two to get a new loan. As the leader, she will spend her entire loan portion to buy fertilizer and rice seed for her crop. She highly hopes that she can gain a better yield than before.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and rice seed for her crop

loans.name: Istifanus

texts.en: Istifanus is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Istifanus joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his child: judith. Istifanus is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Istifanus will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would  be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive, but are often diluted with external products like sand. With access to high quality inputs, Istifanus can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14  and  earn up to $2000/ha, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked, Istifanus said “I plan to use the money I make this year to provide more food and clothing for my family. Istifanus is not thinking about just this year; he said, “in 5 years, I want to become the  most profitable farmer in my community.”

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es:
La Señora Rosa tiene 58 años de edad, es viuda y tiene 3 hijos, donde todos ya son mayores y a quienes ha criado con mucho sacrificio.
Comenta que antes trabajaba de empleada, pero con la muerte de su marido dejó ese trabajo para montar su propio negocio, y con la ayuda de sus hijos, pudo montar un modesto kiosco donde vende frutas y verduras; con mucho trabajo y sacrificio le fue bien en su negocio. Hoy en día cuenta con clientela formada; el préstamo que solicita es para la compra de productos varios para su kiosko como verduras, frutas, golosinas, jugos, etc., ya que con el stock que poseía ya no abastecía más las necesidades de sus clientes y perdía mucha venta con ello, por lo que a través de este préstamo quiere mejorar.
texts.en:
Rosa is 58-year-old widow with three children, who are all grown-up now, and whom she raised with a lot of sacrifices. She says that formerly she used to work as an employee, but after her husband's death, she left this work in order to set up her own business. With the help of her children, she was able to set up a modest kiosk where she could sell fruit and vegetables. Her business prospered through a great deal of sacrifice and hard work, and now she has built up a customer base.

Rosa is asking for a loan to buy several products for her kiosk such as fruit and vegetables, snacks and juice, as she didn't have enough stock to cover her clients' needs and was therefore losing a lot of sales. She hopes to improve matters by means of this loan.

loans.use: to buy goods such as fruit and vegetables, snacks and juice.

loans.name: Ran's Group

texts.en: A mother of five children and a villager from Battambang, Ran is 57 years old. She is a farmer who grows rice and raises pigs as the main source of income. Ran is quite new to VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). Now, she has joined a group of four to get a new loan. As the leader, she will spend her entire loan portion to buy fertilizer and to pay a plowing fee. She hopes that she can gain a better yield than before.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and to pay a plowing fee

loans.name: In's Group

texts.en:

In has been with VisionFund for three cycles. Now she is going to take another loan with VisionFund. She wants to use her portion to buy fertilizer and seeds for her farmland. She hopes this loan will enable her to earn more income from her agribusiness.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seeds for her farmland

loans.name: Rat's Group

This is the first loan for Rat with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). She is teaming up with a group of four to get the first loan. As the representative of her group, Rat will spend her entire loan portion to buy fertilizer for her crop. She hopes to gain a better income than before.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her crop

loans.name: Kimyen's Group

texts.en:
Kimyen is a 57-year-old mother of three who lives in a rural village of the Ou Reang Ov district of Kampong Cham province. 

She and her husband earn a living growing rice as the main source of income. They have been in this business for almost 39 years and earn about 30,000 KHR per day.

Kimyen group consists of two members who live in the same village. She is a second cycle client with VisionFund and has successfully repaid the first loan, which helped her improve her livelihood. 

She is the lead member  applying for a loan to buy fertilizer for her farm. She hopes to grow healthy crops and earn more income to make a living better.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her farm.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ou Reang Ov district

loans.name: Yat's Group

texts.en:
Yat is 58 years old, married with one child, and lives in a wooden house in the Tbaung Khmum district of Kampong Cham province.

The main source of her family’s income is growing rice. She has been in this business for almost 40 years and earns about 29,000KHR per day. 

This is the second loan for Yat and she successfully repaid the loans. She  used the first loan to improve her livelihood. She leads her group to apply for a loan with VisionFund.  She is going to use her portion to buy fertilizer for her farm. She hopes to increase her crop yield and sell it for a good price.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her farm.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Tbaung Khmum district

loans.name: Sokong's Group

texts.en:
Sokong is 33 years old and married. She lives with her husband and three children in a rural area of the Ponhea Krek district of Kampong Cham province. She and her husband are farmers who grow rubber trees. Having been in this business for 13 years, together they can earn about KHR60,000 per day. 

Sokong is a first-cycle client with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund. As the leader, she is going to use her portion to buy fertilizer for her farmland. She hopes this loan will enable her to earn more income from her current business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her farmland

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ponhea Krek district

loans.name: Mun's Group

texts.en:
Mun is 47 years old, married with five children, and resides in a rural village of the Srey Snom district of Siem Reap province. 

She and her husband have grown rice for ten years. Their business earns about 30,000 KHR per day to meet her family’s needs. 

Mun has been a member of Kiva’s partner, VisionFund, for three cycles  and  used the previous loan to provide sufficient food for her family. 

She leads her group and will use her loan portion to buy fertilizer for her farm. She hopes to earn more income from her current business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her farm.

location.town: Siem Reap Province, Srey Snom district
